University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: Forto be wise in byinge of vitail
For wheþir he paide or took be tail
Algate he waitid so on his acate
That he was ay before ⁊and in good state
Now is nat þat of god afair grace
That such a lewd mannys wit shal pace
The wisdom of an heep of lerned men
Of maistris hadde he mo þan thries ten
That were of lawe expert and corious
Of which þer were a dosen in that hous
Worthi to be stuardis of rente and londe
Of eny lord þat is in engelond
To make him lyve be his owen good
In honour detles but he were wood
Othir lyue scarseli as him list desire
And for to helpe al þe shire
In ony cause þat myȝte falle or happe
And þis Mancipil . set al her cappe
A Reve þer was . A slendir colerik man
His berd is shaue as nygh as he can
His heris were be his eris rounde I shore
His top was dockid lik a prest before
Ful longe were his leggis and ful lene
Lik a staf þer nys no calf I sene
Wel coude he kepe a garner and A bynne
Ther was non auditour coude of him wynne
Wel wiste he be þe drouȝte and be þe Rayn
The yeldynge of his seed and of his greyn
His lordis sheep his neet and his deirie
His swyne his hors . his stoor and his pultrie
Was hoolly in þis Revys gouernynge
And bi his covenaunt yaf þe rekenynge
Seth his lord was xxᵗⁱ . yeer of age
Ther coude noman brynge him in rerage
Þer nas bailli ne noon oþer hyne
Þat coude his sleyȝte or his couyne
They were of him a drad as of þe deth
His wonynge was fair vp on an heth
With grene treis shadowed was his place
He coude better þanne his lord purchace
Ful riche he was astored pryuely
His lord he coude please discreetli
To yeue ayen to him of his owen good
And haue þank ⁊and yet acote ⁊and an hood
In youthe he hadde lerned agood mystere
He was a wel good wriȝt a Carpentere
This Reve sat vpon a wel good stot
That was al pomel gray ⁊and hiȝte scot
A long surcote of Perce vp on him he hadde
And bi his side . he baar a rusty bladde
Of Norfolk was þis Reve of which I telle
Be side a toun men calle Baldiswelle
Tuckid he was as is a frere aboute
And euer he rood þe hynderest of þe Rowte
Asompnour with vs was in þat place
That hadde a reed cherubyn face
For sawsfleme he was with yen narow
Hoot he was and likerous as a sparow
With blake browes skallid ⁊and piled berd
Of his visage children were a ferd
Ther nas quyc siluer . litarge ne brimstone
Borace ceruze ne oile of tartir none
Ne oynement þat ichith or bite
That myȝte helpe of his welkis white
Ne of his knobbis sittynge in his chekis
Well loued he oynons garleek and lekis
And forto drynke reed wyne as red as blood
Thanne wolde he speke ⁊and crie as he wer wood
And whanne he hadde wel dronke þe wyn
Thanne wolde he speke no word but latyn
Afewe termes hadde he . two . or thre
That he hadde lerned of sum man of degre
No wondir is . herde he it al þe day
That eke ye knowe wel þat a Iay
Can clepe watte as wel as þe Pope
But who coude him in oþer þyngis grope
Thouȝ he spent al his philosofie
A questio quid queris wolde he crie
He was a gentil harlot ⁊and a kynde
A bettir felow sholde no man fynde
He wolde suffre for a quart of wyn
A good felow to haue his concubyn
A twelf monthe . ⁊and excuse him at þe fulle
Ful pryueli a fynch eke coude he pulle
And if he fond owher a good felawe
He wolde teche him anon to haue awe
In such caas . of þe Archedekenes curs
But yf mannys soule were in his purs
For in his purs he sholde I pynchid be
Purs is þe Archedekenes hele saide he
But wel I woot . he lied in dede
Of cursynge owght ech man to drede
For cursinge wil sle riȝt as soilynge saveth
And also ware him of significauit
In daunger hadde he at his owen gise
The yonge girlis of þe diocyse
And knew of hir counsel ⁊and was of her rede
A garlond he hadde set vp on his hede
As greet as it were an Alestake
A bokeler hadde he maad him of A Cake
With . him þer rood a gentil pardoner
Of Runcyuale his frend ⁊and his comper
That streyȝt was come fro þe Pope of Rome
Ful lowde he song com hider loue grom
This sompnour baar to him a stif burdoıı̄un
Was neuer trompe of half so greet A soun
This pardoner hadde yeer as yelow as wex
And smothe it hyng as doth a strike of flex
Bi ownsis . hyng his lockis þat he hadde
And þere with his sholdris over spradde
But þanne it lay be Culpons . one and one
An hood for cold wered he none
For it was trussed vp on his walet
Him thouȝte he rood vp on þe newe get
Disshevill saue his cappe he rood albare
Such glarynge yen hadde he as hath an hare
His walet beforn him in his lappe
A vernacle hadde he sowid vp on his cappe
Bred ful of pardou com fro Rome al hoot
A vois he hadde as smal as hath a goot
No berd hadde he ne neuer sholde haue
As moche was it as it were newe shave
I trowe he were a geldyng or a mare
But of his craft from Berwik vnto Ware
Ne was þer such a pardoner
For in his male he hadde A pilow beer
Whiche þat he saide was our ladies veill
He saide he hadde a gobet of þe seill
That saint Petir hadde when þᵗat he went
Vp on the se til Iesus crist him hent
He hadde a cros of laton ful of stones
And in a glas he hadde piggis bones
But wᵗith thise reliques whan þᵗat he fond
A poer ꝑperson dwellynge vp on lond
Vp on a day he gat him more mone
Than þe person gat in monethis thre
And þus hath he feyned flateriez ⁊and Iapis
He made þe parson ⁊and þe pepill his apis
But trewli to telle at þe last
He was in chirche an noble ecclesiast
Well coude he rede a lesson or a story
But alderbest he song an Innaatory
For wel he wiste whan þᵗat song was sunge
He moste preche ⁊and file awhile his tunge
To wynne siluer as he wel can .
Therfore he song þe merier than
NOw haue I tolde yow shortly in a clause
Þe state þe aray þᵉ nombre ⁊and þe cause
Whi þᵗat assembled was þis companie
In Sowthwerk at þis gentil hostelrie
That highte þe Taberd faste bi þe belle
But now is tyme to you forto telle
How þᵗat we bare vs þᵗat ilke nyȝt
Whanne þat were in þe hostry aliȝt
And aftir wil I telle of our viage
And al þe remenaunt of our pilgremage
But first I you pray of your curtasie
That ye ne rekene nat my vilonye
Though þat I playnly speke in þis matere
To telle you here wordis and hir chere
And þouȝ I speke here wordis propirly
For þis ye knowe as wel as I
Who shal a tale telle aftir aman
He moste reherce as nere as he can
Euery word if it be in his charge
Al speke he so rudely and so large
Or ellis he moste telle his tale vntrewe
Or seyn þyngis or feyne wordis newe
He may not spare al þouȝ he were his broþ
He moot as wel say . o word as anothir
Crist spak him self ful brode in holy writ
And well ye woot no vilany is it
Eke plato saith who so can it rede
Þe word moste be cosyn to þe dede
Also I pray you foryeue it me
Al þouȝ I sette not folk in hir degre
Here in þize tales as þey sholde stonde
Mi wit is short ye may wel vnderstonde
GReet chere made our ost to vs euerichon
And to sopere sette vs anone
He serued vs with vitaill at þe beste
Strong was þe wyne ⁊and drynke vs liste
A semely man our host was wᵗith alle
Forto be a Marchal in an halle
A large man he was wᵗith yen stepe
A feirer burgeys is þer non in chepe
Bold of his speche and wel was I tauȝt
And of manhood lacked he riȝt nouȝt
Eke þerto was he riȝt a mery man
And aftir soper to pleyen he began
And spak of myrthe among oþer þyngez
Whanne þᵗat we hadde made our rekenynggez
He saide þus . now lordyngez trewly
Ye be to me riȝt welcome hertly
For be my trowthe yf þᵗat I shal not ly
I saw nat þis yeer so mery a company
At onys in þis harborow as now
Feyne wolde I do you myrthe If y wiste how
And of my myrthe I am i riȝt now be þouȝt
To do you eze and it shal coste you nouȝt
Ye go to Caunterbury god you spede
Þe blisful martir quyte your mede
And wel ye woot as ye go be þe weye
Ye shapyn you to talke and to pleye
For trewly comfort ne myrthe is non
To ride be þe wey dom as a stoon
And þerfore wil I make you disport
As I saide erst and do you comfort
And if it liketh you alle be on assent
Forto stonde at my iugement
And forto worke as I shal you say
To morow whanne ye riden on þe way
Now be my fader soule þat is ded
But ye be mery I shal yeue you my hed
Hold vp your hond wᵗithoute more speche
Our counsel shal not longe be to seche
Vs þouȝte it was not worth to make vs wise
And graunted him withoute more avise
And bad him say his verdit as him list
Lordynges ꝙquod he now herkeneth for þe best
But take it not I pray you in dysdeyne
This is þe poynt to speke it short ⁊and pleyn
That ech of you to shorte with your wey
In þis viage shal telle talis twey
To Cauntirbury ward I mene it so
And homward he shal telle oþer talis to
Of auenturis þat whilom haue befalle
And which of you berith him best of alle
That is to sey þat tellith in þis case
Tales of best sentence ⁊and most solace
Shal haue a soper of oure alther cost
Here in þis place sittynge bi þis post
Whanne þᵗat we come ayen from Caunterbury
And forto make you þe more mery
I wil my self go with you and ride
Riȝt at myn owen cost and be your gide
And who þat wol my iugement with say
Shortly al þat is spent be þe way
And if vouche saaf þat it be so
Tel me anone withoute wordis mo
And I wil hertly shape me þerfore
This þing was graunted ⁊and othis swore
With ful glad herte ⁊and preyen him also
Þat he wolde fowche saf to do so
And þat he wolde be our gouernour
And of oure talis Iuge ⁊and reportour
And sette a soper at a certayn price
And wol be rewlid at his deuyce
High and lowe ⁊and alle be on assent
We be accorded to the iugement
And þere vp on þe wyne was fet anone
We dronk . and to reste went we echone
Wᵗithoute eny lenger taryynge
Amorow whan þe day gan sprynge
Vp roos our host and was al our cok
And gadred vs alle in a flok
And forth we riden litil more þanne A paas
Vnto þe waterynge of saint Thomas
And þere our hoste gan his hors areste
And saide harkeneth lordingez as ye liste
Ye woot our forward and I you Recorde
Yf euensyng and morow song acorde
Let se now . who shal telle þe firste tale .
As evir moot he drynke wyne or Ale
Who so wil be rebel to my iugement
Shal paie for al þᵗat is be þe way spent
Now draw cut or þᵗat ye further twynne
Which shal þe firste tale begynne
Sire knyȝt ꝙquod he my maister ⁊and my lord
Drawith cut for þat is myn accord
Cometh hithir ꝙquod he my lady Prioresse
And ye ʆsir clerk let be your shamefastnesse
Ne stody not ley on hond euery man
Anon to withdrawe euery wight began
And shortly to telle as it was
Were it be auenture sortune sort fortune or caas
The soth is þis þe cut fil on þe knyȝt
Of which ful blithe and glad is euery wiȝt
And telle he moste as it was reson
Be forward and be composicion̄
As ye haue herd what nedith wordis mo
And whanne þis good man saw þᵗat it was so
As he þat was wise ⁊and obedient
To kepe his forward be his fre assent
He saide sithnes I shal begynne þe game
What welcom be cut a goddis name
Now lat vs ride and herkyn what I say
And with þat word we riden forth on þe way
And he began with riȝt a mery chere
And saide anone his / tale as ye shul here
Here bigynneth þe knyȝtis tale
Whilom as olde story telleth vs
Ther was a duke þᵗat hiȝte Theseus
Of thebes he was lord ⁊and gouernour
And in his tyme such a conquerour
Þat gretter was þer none vnder sonne
Ful many a Riche contre had he wonne
That with his wisdom ⁊and his chiualrie
He conquered al þe regne of femenye
That whilom was cleped Citha
And wedded þe quene Ipolita
And brouȝte hir hom in to his contre
With moche glorie and solempnite
And eke hir yonge suster Emelye
And þus with victory and melodye
Lete I þis worthi duke to Athenes ride
And al his ost in armes him beside
And certis if it nere to long to here
I wolde haue told fulli þe matere
How wonne was þe regne of femenye
Be Theseus and bi his chiualrie
And of þe grete bataille for þe nonys
Betwix Athenes and Amasones
And how beseged was Ipolita
The faire lady quene of Cithea
And of þe feste þat was at hir weddynge
And atte Tempest at hir hom comynge
But al þinge I moot as now forbere
I haue god wot a large feld to ere
And week bith þe oxen in þe plow
The remenant of my tale is long ynow
I wil not lette eke none of þis rowte
Let euery felow telle his tale abowte
And let se now who shal þe soper wynne
And þere I lefte I wil agayn begynne
THis duke of whom I make mencion
Whan he was come almost in to þᵉ ton̄
He was ware as he cast his ye aside
In al his welthe and his most pride
Where þat þer kneled in þe high wey
A companye of ladies twey and twey
Ech aftir oþer clothed in clothes blake
But such a cry and such a wo þey make
That in þis worlde nys creature lyuyng
That herde such anoþer weymentynge
And of þis cry þey wolde neuer stentyn
Til þey þe reynys of his bridil hentyn
What folk be ye þat at myn hom comyng
Perturbe me and my feste wᵗith cryynge
Quod Theseus haue ye so gret envye
Of myn honour þat þus compleyne ⁊and crie
Or who hath you mysboden or offended
Tel me and it shal be amended
And whi þᵗat ye be clothed þus in blak
The eldest lady of ham alle spak
Whanne she hadde swowned wᵗith a dedly chere
That it was rowthe to se and to here
She saide lord to whom fortune hath yeve
Victory and as a conquerour to lyve
Nouȝt greueth vs your glori and yoᵘur honour
But we beseke you of mercy and socour
Haue mercy on our wo and distresse
Som drope of pite for thi gentilnesse
Vp on vs wrecchid wommen let now falle
For certis lord þer is non of vs alle
That she ne hath be a duchesse or a quene
Now be we caitifs as it is wel sene
I thanked be fortune ⁊and hir fals wheel
That non astat ensureth to be wel
Now certis lord to abide in yoᵘur p̉resence
Here in þis temple of goddis clemence
We haue be waitynge al þis fourtenyȝt
Now help vs lord seth it is in thi myght
O Wrecched wyȝt þᵗat wepe þus
Was somtyme wif of Campaneus
That starf at Thebes acursid be þᵗat day
And alle we þᵗat ben in þis aray
And make al þis lamentacioıı̄un
We losten alle our housbondis in þᵗat toun
Whilez þe sege þere aboute lay
And yet now þe olde creon wel away
That lord is now of Thebes þat cite
Fulfilled of Ire and iniquite
He for despit and his tirannye
To do þe ded bodies vilonye
Of alle our lordis which þᵗat ben slawe
Hath alle þe bodiez on an heep Idrawe
And wol not suffre ham be non assent
Neither to be buried ne to be brent
But makith houndis to ete hem in despit
And with þat word withoute more respit
They fallen groflynge ⁊and crye pitously
Haue on vs wrecchid wommen som mercy
And let our sorow synke in thi hert
Þis gentil duke doun of his courser stert
With herte pitous whenne he herde he speke
Him þouȝte his herte wolde breke
Whan he saw ham so pitous ⁊and so mate
That whilom were of so greet astate
And in his armes he hem alle vp hent
And hem comforted in ful good entent
And swor͗e his oth as he was trewe knyȝt
He wolde do so ferforth his myȝt
Vp on þe tiraunt Creon him to wreke
That al þe pepil of grece sholde speke
How Creon was of Theseus yserued
As he hath his deth wel deserued
And riȝt anon withouten more abood
His baner he displaide and forth he rood
To tebes ward and al his oste beside
No ner Athenes nolde he go ne ride
Ne take his ese nat fully half aday
But on his wey þat nyȝt he lay
And sente anon Ipolita þe quene
And Emely hir yonge sustir shene
Vnto þe toun of Athenes to dwelle
And forth he rideth þer is no more telle
HE rood þe statu wᵗith spere ⁊and targe
So shyneth in his whit baner large
That alle þe feldis gliteren vp and doun
And be his baner born is his penon
Of gold ful riche in which þer was Ibete
The Mythan which he wan in Grece
This riche duke þis riche conquerour
And in his ost of chiualrie þe flowr
Til þᵗat he cam to tebes and alighte
Fer in a feld þere as he þouȝte to fiȝte
But shortli to speke of þis þyng
With Creon which was of thebes kyng
He fauȝt and slow him manly as a knyȝt
In playn bataille ⁊and put his folk to fhȝt
And Att a sawt he won þe cite Aftir
And rente adoun wal speer ⁊and raftir
And to þe ladies he restored ageyn̄
The bonys of her husbondꝭes þᵗat were sleyn̄
To do obsequyes as þo was þe gise
But it were al to long to deuyse
The grete clamour ⁊and þe weymentyng
The ladies made of þe burying
Of þe bodies ⁊and þe grete honour͗
That Theseus þe nobil conquerour͗
Doth to þe ladiez when þey fro him went
But shortli forto telle is myn entent
When þat þis worthi duke þis Theseus
Hath Creon slayn̄ ⁊and wan Thebes þus
Stille in þe felde he took al nyȝt his rest
And dide with al þe contre riȝt as him list
He ransaked in þe taas of bodies dede
Ham for to stripe of harneis ⁊and of wede
The pilours dide hir besinesse and cure
Aftir þe bataille and þe to discomfiture
And befil þat in þat taas þey fond
Thorow girt with meny a greuous wound
Two yonge knyȝtis lyinge by and by
Bothe in one harneis wrouȝt ful richeli
Of whiche two Arcite highte þat one
And the othir hiȝte Palamon̄e
Not fulli quyk ne fulli ded þey were
But by hir cote armur͗e ⁊and bi hir gere
The herowdes knew ham best in special
Alas that þey were of þe blood rial
Of Thebes and of sustryn two Ibore
Out of the taas þe pilours haue ham tore
And haue ham caried in to þe tent
Of Theseus ⁊and he ful sone ham sent
To Athenes to dwelle þere in prison̄
Perpetuel he nolde no Raunson
And whan þis worthi duke hadde þus ydon
He took his ost ⁊and hom he goth anon̄
With laure coroned as a conquerour͗
And there he lyueth in ioie ⁊and in honour͗
Terme of his lif what nedith wordis mo
And in a tour with anguysh ⁊and wᵗith wo
Duellith Palamon and Arcite
For euermore ther may no man ham quyte
THus passed yeer be yer day be day
Til it fil ones in a mornynge of May
That Emeli þat fair was to se
Þanne is þe lili vp on þe stalk tre
And fressher͗ þan may wᵗith flowris newe
For with þe rose colour stroof hir hewe
I not which was þe feirer of ham two
Er it was day as was her wont to do
She was arisen and al redy dight
For may wol haue no slogard a nyght
The seson pricketh eueri gentil herte
And maketh it out of his slepe sterte
And sithnes a rise to do hir obseruauncis
This makith Emeli to haue remembrauncis
To do honure to May and forto rise
Iclothed fressh was she to deuyse
Her yelow her was broided on a tres
Be hynd her bak a long yerd I ges
And in þe gardyn at the sonne vprist
She walked vp and doun as hir list
She gadred flowris part white ⁊and rede
To make A sotel chapelet for hir hed
And as an aungel heuenly she sang
The grete tour þat was so thicke ⁊and strang
Which of þe Castel was chief dungeoun
There as þe knyȝtis weren in prisoun
Of which I tolde you ⁊and telle shal
Was evene ioynant to þe Castel wal
There as þis Emely had her pleyyng
Bryȝt was þe sonne ⁊and cleer in þat mornynge
And Palamon this woful pers pers prisoner
As was his wone be leve of his gailer
Was risen and romed in the chambir on hy
In whiche he al þe noble cite sy
And eke þe gardyn ful of braunchis grene
There as fressh Emely þe shene
Was in hir walk ⁊and romed vp and doun
This sorowful prisoner þis Palamoun̄
Goth in þe chambir to and fro
And to him self compleyned of his wo
That he was born̄ ful ofte he saide allas
And so be fil be auenture and caas
Þat þorow a wyndow thikke of many a barre
Of iren greet and squaar as eny sparre
He cast his yen vp on Emelie . A .
And ther with as he blente he cride . A .
As þouȝ he were stongyn to the hert
And with þat cry Arcite anone vp stert
And saide cosyn myn what eileth the
That art so pale and dedly on to se
Whi criest thou who hath do the offence
For goddis loue take al in pacience
Our prison for it may non oþer be
Fortune hath yeue vs þis aduersite
Or ellis som wicked aspect or disposicion̄
Of saturne be som constillacion
Hath yeue vs þis al þey we had sworn̄
So stood the heuene whan þᵗat were born̄
We moste endure þis is þe short ⁊and playn̄
This Palamon ansuerd and saide agayn̄
Cosyn forsothe of þis oppinion̄
Thow hast aveyn ymaginacion̄
This prison cawsid me not to crye
But I was hurt riȝt now þoruȝ out mȳn ye
Into my hert þat wol my bane be
Þe fairnesse of a lady þat I se
Yonder in þe gardyn romynge to ⁊and fro
Is cause of my cryynge and my wo
I not wheþer she be womman or goddesse
But Venus it is sothli as I gesse
And therwith al on knees doun he fil
And saide venus if it be thi wil
Yow in þis gardyn þus to transfigure
Before me sorowful wrecche þy creature
Out of þis prison help þat we may scape
And if it be my destenye so to hape
Be etern worlde to dye in prison
Of our lynage haue som compassion̄
That is so lowe Ibrouȝt be tiranny
And with þat word Arcite gan espie
Where as þe lady wente to and fro
And with þat sighte her beaute hurte him so
That if Palamon were wounded sore
Arcite is hurt as moche as he or more
And with a sigh . he sighed pitously
The fresh beaute shal sle me sodenly
Of hire þat rometh in þe yonder place
And but I haue hir mercy and hir grace
That I may se her at þe leste wey
I am but ded þer is no more to sey
THis Palamon when he þise wordis herd
Dispitousli he loked and ansuerd
Whethir saist thow þis in ernest or in play
Nay qduod Arcite in ernest be my fay
God helpe so me lust ful litil to play
This Palamon gan knytte his browis tway
Hit were quod he to þe no gret honour
Forto be fals ne to be a traitour
To me þat am þi cosyn ⁊and þi broþer
Isworn ful depe and ech of vs to oþer
That neuer forto dien in peyn̄
Til þat þe deth departe shal vs tweyn̄
Neither in loue to hyndre oþer
Ne in no evil caas my leve broþer͗
But þᵗat þou sholdest truly further me
In euery caas as I sholde further þe
Þis was þyn oth and myn certayn
I woot it wel þᵘou darst it not withsayn
Thus art thou of my counsel withoute doute
And now þou woldist falsli be aboute
To loue my lady whom I loue ⁊and serue
And euyr shal til myn herte sterue
Now certis fals Arcite þᵘou shalt not so
I loued hir first and tolde the my wo
As to my counsel and to my broþer sworn̄
I suppose þᵘou louedist hir here beforn̄
Wost þou not wel þe olde clerkis sawe
That we shal yeue a louer eny lawe
Loue is gretter lawe be my panne
Than may be yeue to eny erthli manne
And þerfore positif lawe and such degre
Is broken alday for loue in ech degre
Aman moste nedis loue magre his hed
He may not fle it þouȝ he sholde be ded
Al be she maide widowe or wif
And eke it is not likly al thi lif
To stonde in her grace nomore shal I
For wel þᵘou wost þi self verili
That þou and I be dampned to prison
Perpetualli vs gayneth no raunson
Ne stryve as did þe houndis for þe bon
They fauȝt alday ⁊and yet her part was non
Ther cam a curre while þᵗat þey were so wroth̄e
And baar awey þe bon betwix ham bothe
And þerfore at þe kyngis court my broþer
Ech man for him self þere is non oþer
Loue if þou list for I loue shal and shal
And sothli leue broþer þis is al
Here in þis prison moste we endure
And euery of vs take his auenture
Gret was þe strif and long betwix ham twey
Yf þat I hadde leiser forto sey
But to þe effect it happed on a day
To telle it shortli as I may
A Worthi duke þat hiȝte Parotheus
Þat felow was to duke Theseus
But of þᵗat story list me not to endite
Duke Parotheus loued wel Arcite
And hadde him knowe at thebes yeer be yeer
And finalli at þe request and praier
Of Parotheus withoute eny Raunson
Duke Theseus leet him out of prison
Freli to go where him list ouer al
In such a gise as I you telle shal
This was þe forward playnli to endite
Betwix duke Theseus and Arcite
That if so were þᵗat Arcite were founde
Euer in his lif be day or be stounde
In eny contre of this duke Theseus
And he were cawȝt it was acorded þus
That with a swerd he sholde leze his hed
Þer was non oþer remedy ne reed
But takith his leve ⁊and homward him spedde
Let him bewaar his lif lith to wedde
Hit were a gret þing to telle ⁊and to trete
How greet sorow now suffrith Arcite
Now is me shapyn eternalli to dwelle
Nouȝt in purgatory but in helle
Allas þᵗat ever knew I Parotheus
For ellis hadde I duelt with Theseus
Ifedered in his prison with mo
Thanne hadde I be in eze and not in wo
Onli þe siȝte of hir whom þat I serve
Þouȝ þat I neuer her grace may deserve
Wolde haue suffized riȝt ynow for me
O dere cosyn Palamon qduod he
Thyn is þe victory and þis auenture
Ful blisful in prison mayst þou endure
In prison nay certis in paradise
Wel hath fortune turned þe dise
That hath þe siȝte of hir in myn absence
For possible it is sethnes þᵘou hast hir presence
And art a knyȝt worthi ⁊and habill
That bi som caas syn fortune is chaungeable
Thou mayst som tyme to thi desire atteyne
But I þat am exiled ⁊and bareyne
Of alle grace and so in gret despeir͗
That þer nys watir erthe fire ne eir͗
Ne creature that of ham made is
That may me helpe or comfort do Iwis
Wel oughte I sterve in wanhope ⁊and distres
Farwel my lif my lust ⁊and my gladnes
Allas whi playnen men so in cōmmune
Of purueaunce of good or of fortune
That yeueth ham ofte in meny wise
Wel bettir thanne ham self can deuyse
Som men desire to haue richesse
Þat cause is of mordre or gret siknesse
And som man wolde out of his prison feyn
That in his hous of his meyne is sleyn̄
Infynyt harmes be in this matere
We wot not what þing we praie here
We faren as he þᵗat dronke is as a mous
A dronken man wot wel he hath an hows
But he wot not which is þe riȝte wey þider
To a dronkyn man þe wey is slidir
And certis in this worlde so fare we
We sekyn faste aftir felicite
But we go wrong ful ofte sikirly
Þus may we say alle ⁊and nameli I
That wente haue had a gret oppinion̄
Þat and I myȝte scape out of prison̄
Thanne hadde I be in ioie ⁊and in ꝑparfit hele
Ther now I am exiled fro myn hele
Sithnes I may not se you Emelie
I ne am but ded þer is no remedie
Vpon þat oþer side Palamon
Whanne þat he wiste Arcite was goon̄
Such sorou he makith þᵗat þe grete tour
Resouned of his yellyng and his clamour͗
The pure feteris on his shynys grete
Were of his bittir salt teris wete
Allas quod he Arcite cosyn myn
Of al our strif god woot þe fruyt is thyn
Thou walkist now in thebes at thi large
And of my wo þou yeuest litil charge
Thou maist say þᵘou hast wisdom ⁊and manhede
Assembil alle þe folk of our kynrede
And make warre so sharp on this contre
That bi som auenture or trete
Thou maist haue hir to lady ⁊and to wif
For whom I muste nedis lese my lif
For as bi wey of possibilite
Sithnes þou art at large ⁊and of prison fre
And art a lord gret is þyn auauntage
More þanne is myn shit her in a cage
For I may wepe and waile whilis þᵗat I lyve
With al þe wo þᵗat prison may me yeue
And eke with peyne þᵗat loue me yeuyth also
That doublith al my turment ⁊and my wo
Therwith þe fire of ielosie vp stert
With ynne his brest ⁊and hent him bi þe hert
So woodly þat he likly was to beholde
The box tre or þe ash tre ded or colde
That saide se o cruel goddis þᵗat gouerne
The worlde with bidyng of your word eterne
And writen in þe tabil of þe athamaunde
Your parlement ⁊and your etern gaudent
What is mankynde more vnto you holde
Thanne is the sheep̄ þᵗat roukith in þe folde
For slayn is man riȝt as anothir beest
And duellith eke in prison and in arest
And hath siknesse and gret aduersite
And ofte tyme giltlees parde
What gouernaille is in his p̉rescience
That giltles turmentith Innocence
And yet encresith þis al my penaunce
That man is bounde to his obseruaunce
For goddis sake to lettyn of his wil
There as a beest may al his wil fulfil
And whanne a beest is ded he hath no peyne
But aftir his deth man may wepe ⁊and playne
Thouȝ in this worlde he haue care and wo
Withoute doute it may stonde so
The ansuer of this lete I to devynes
But wel I woot þᵗat in þis worlde gret pyne ys
Allas I se a serpent or a theef
That many a trew man hath do myschief
Goon at his large ⁊and where him lust may turne
But I muste be in prison þoruȝ saturne
And þoruȝ him I alone ⁊and eek wood
That hath destroid wel nyȝ al my blood
Of thebes with his wast wallis wide
And venus sleeth me in þat oþer side
For Ielosie and seer of him ⁊and Arcite
Now wol I stynte of Palamon alite
And lete him in his prison stille duelle
And of Arcite forth I wol you telle
The somer passed þe nyȝtis wax long
Encrecith be doubil wise þe peynes strong
Boþe of þe louer ⁊and of þe prisoner
I woot he hath þe wofuller myster
For shortli to say of þis Palamon̄
ꝐPerpetuelly is dampned to prison
In cheynys and in fetheris to be ded
And Arcite is exiled be his hed
For euermore and out of þat contre
For nevir more shal he his lady se
Yow louers axe I now this question̄
Who hath þe worse of Arcite ⁊and of Palamon
That one may se his lady b b day be day
But in pⁱrison moste he dwelle alway
That oþer where him list may ride or go
But se his lady shal he neuer mo
Now demyth as ye list ye þat can
For I wil telle forth as I began
Whanne þᵗat Arcite to Thebes come was
div.note: nᵃota
div.l: Ful ofte aday he swelte ⁊and saide allas
For se his lady shal he neuer mo
And shortli to conclude all his wo
So muche sorow ne hath creature
That is or shal be while þᵉ world may dure
His sleep his mete his drynk is him beraft
That lene he wax and drye as is a shaft
His yen holow and grisli to be holde
His hewe falow ⁊and pale as Asshyn colde
And solitary he was and euer a lone
And waylynge as he myȝte makyng his mone
And if he herde song or instrument
Thanne wolde he wepe he myȝt not stent
So febil were his spiritis ⁊and he so lowe
And chaunged so that no man cowde hīm knowe
His speche ne his vois þouȝ men it herde
As in his gire for al þe worlde it ferde
Nouȝt lik þe lovers maladye
Of heris but Rathir Ilik to many
Engendrid of humour malencolie
Beforn his cell fantasie
And shortly turned was al vp so doun̄
Bothe habit ⁊and disposicion
Of him þis woful lover dan Arcite
What sholde I of his wo Alday endite
Whan he endured hadde a yeer or two
This cruel turment þis peyne ⁊and woo
At Thebes in his contre as I saide
Vpon a nyȝt in slepe as he him laide
Him thouȝte how þᵗat he venged Mercury
Beforn him stood and bad him be mery
His slepi ȝerd he baar in hond vpriȝt
An hat he baar vpon his heris briȝt
Araid was this god as he took kepe
As he was whan Argus took his slepe
And saide him þus to Athenez þᵘou shalt wend
There is the shapp̄ of thi wo ⁊and ende
And with þat word Arcite awook ⁊and stert
Now trewly how sore þat me smert
Quod he to Athenes wil I fare
Ne for no drede of deth shal I spare
To se my lady þat I serve
In her p̉resence recke I not to sterve
And with þat word he cauȝte a gret myroᵘur
And saw þat chaunged was his colour
And saw his visage al in a nothir kynde
And riȝt anon it ron him in his mynde
That sithnes his face was disfigured
Of maladye þe which he hadde endured
He myȝte wel if that he bare him lowe
Lyue in Athenes euermore vnknowe
And se his lady wel ny day be day
And riȝt anon he chaunged his Aray
And clad him as a poer laborer
And alone save only a poer squyer
That knew his priuite ⁊and his caas
Which was disgised poerly as he was
To Athenes is he gon þe nexte way
And to the court he wente vp on aday
And at þe gate he profrid his seruize
To drug ⁊and to drawe ⁊and what men wolde deuyse
And shortly of þis mater forto seyn
He fil in office toward A Chambirleyn̄
The whiche þat was dwellyng wᵗith Emelie
For he was wise ⁊and wel coude aspie
Of euery seruaunt which þᵗat serued þere
Wel coude he hewe wode and watir bere
For he was yong ⁊and myȝti for þe nonys
And þerto he was strong ⁊and big of bonys
To do þat eny wiȝt hym coude deuyse
A yeer or two he was in þis seruize
Page in the Chambir of Emely þe briȝte
And Philostrat he saide þᵗat he hiȝte
But half so well aloved man i i as he
Ne was ther non in court of his degre
He was so gentil of condicion
That þurȝ al þe court was his renoun
The saide þat it was charite
That Theseus wolde enhaunse his degre
And put him in a worshipful seruize
There þat he myȝte his vertu excercise
And þus with ynne a while his name spro͒ng
Bothe of his dedis and of his tong
That Theseus hath take him so nere
That of his chambir he made him a squiere
And yaf him gold to mayntene his degre
And eke men brouȝte him out of his contr͗e
Fro yeer to yeer ful pryueli his rente
But honestly and slighli he it spente
That no man wondred how þᵗat he it hadde
And thre yeer in þis wise his lif he ladde
And baar him in pees ⁊and eke in warre
Ther was noman þᵗat Theseus hadde derre
And in this blisse lete I now Arcite
And speke I wil of Palamon alite
In derknesse horrible and in strong prison
This seven yeer hath sete þis Palamon̄
For pyned what for wo ⁊and distresse
Who felith dowbil wo and heuynesse
But Palamon þat loue distreyneth so
That wood out of his wit he ny goth for wo
And eke þerto he is a prisoner
Perpetuel and not only for a yeer
Who cowde ryme in englissh propirly
His martirdom forsothe it am not I
Therfore I passe as liȝtly as I may
The thridde nyȝt as olde bokis sayn
That all þis story tellith more ⁊and playn
Were it be auenture or disteyn̄e
Alas þᵗat whan a þing is shapyn it shal be
That sone aftir þe mydnyȝt Palamon̄
Be help of a frend broke hath his prison̄
And fleeth fro þe pⁱrison as sone as he may go
For he hadde yeue his gailer drynke so
Of clarrey made of certayn wyne
With nercotises and Epie of Thebes fyne
That half þat nyȝt þouȝ men wolde hȳm shake
The gailer so slepte he myȝte not awake
And þus he fly as faste as he may
The nyȝt was short ⁊and faste be þe day
That nedis cost he moste him self hide
And to a grove faste beside
With dredful herte than stalketh Palamōn
For shortly þis was his oppinion̄
That in þat grove he wolde him hide alday
And in þe nyȝt than wolde he take his way
To Thebes ward his frendis forto prey
On Theseus to helpe him verrey
And shortli eyther he wolde leze his liff
Or wynne Emelye to his wiff
This is þe effect ⁊and þe entent playn
Now wil I turne to Arcite agayn̄
That litil wiste how nygh was his care
Til þat fortune had brouȝt him in þᵉ snare
The mery larke messanger of May
Salueth in hir song þe morow gray
And firy phebus risith vs so briȝt
That al þe orient lawghith of þe siȝt
And with his stremys driuyth in þe leuys
The siluer droppis hangynge on þe levys
And Arcita that in the court rial
With Theseus his squier principal
Is risyn and lokyn on the mery day
And forto do his obseruaunce to May
Remembrynge on the poynt of his desir͗e
He on his courser stirtinge lik þe fire
Is riden in to þe feldis him to pleye
Out of the Court were it a myle or tweye
And to þe grove of which þᵗat I you tolde
By auenture his wey he gan to holde
To make him a garlond of þe grevis
Were it of wodebynde or of hawthorn levys
And lowde he song ayens þe sonne shene
May al thi flowris ⁊and thi grene
Welcome be thou fressh faire May
In hope þat I som greve gete may
And fro his courser with a lusty hert
In to þe grove ful lusteli he stert
And in a path he romed vp and doun
Where as bi auenture this Palamoıı̄un
Was in a bussh þᵗat noman myȝte him se
Ful sore a ferd of his deth was he
No þing knew he þat þis was Arcite
God woot he wolde haue trowed it ful lite
But soth is said . go sithnes is many yeris
That feld hath yen and wode hath eris
Hit is ful fair aman to bere him evyn
For alday men metith at vnset setveyn̄
For litil wente Arcite of his felaw
That was so nygh to herkyn of his saw
Whanne þᵗat Arcite hadde romed al his fiƚƚlle
Palamon in the bush now sittith stille
And Arcite song al þe roundel lustily
Into a study he fil sodenly
As doon thize lovers in hir queynte giris
Now in the crop̄ and now in the breris
Now vp now doun as boket in a welle
Riȝt as þe friday sothli forto telle
Now it shyneth now it rayneth fast
Riȝt so gan guerri venus ouer cast
The hertes of her folk riȝt as her day
His guerful riȝt so chaungeth his aray
Selde is þe friday al þe woke lik
Whan þat Arcite hadde songe he begān to sike
And he set him doun wᵗithoute eny more
Allas ꝙquod he the day þat I was bore
How longe Iuno þurȝ thi cruelte
Wilt thow werien thebes the Cite
Alas Ibrouȝt is to confusion̄
The blood Rial of Cadyn ⁊and Amphion̄
Of Cadmus which þᵗat was þe firste man
That Thebes bilt or first þe toun began
And of the cite first was crouned kyng
Of his lynage am I and of his ofsring
Be verray lyne and of stok Rial
And now I am so caitif and so thral
That he þᵗat is my mortal enemy
I serve him ⁊and am his squier poverly
And yet doth me Iuno welmore shame
For y dar not beknowe myn owen name
But þere as I wont was to hiȝte Arcite
Now hiȝte I Philostrat not worth amyte
Allas þou fel mars allas Iuno
Thus hath your ire our lynage al fordo
Saue onli on wrecchid Palamon̄
That Theseus martrith in prison̄
An all ouer this to sle me vtterly
Loue hath his firy dart so brennyngly
It stikid þoruȝ my trew careful hert
That shapen was erst my deth or my shert
Ye sle me with your yen Emelie
Ye be þe cause wherfore þat I dye
Of al the Remenaunt of myn other care
Ne sette I not the mountaunce of A tare
So that I coude do auȝt to your plesaunce
And with þat word he fil doun in A traunce
Alonge tyme and Aftirward vp stert
This Palamon þᵗat þouȝte thorow his hert
He felt a cold swerd sodeynli glide
For Ire he quoke he nolde no lengir͗ Abide
And whanne þᵗat he hath herd Arcites tale
As he were wood with face ded and pale
He stirt him vp out of the bussh thicke
And saide Arcite fals traitour wicke
Now art thou hent þᵗat louest my lady so
For whom þat I haue this peyne and wo
And art my blood and to my counsel sworn̄
And I ful ofte haue told the here beforn̄
And hast beiapid here duke Theseus
And falsli hast chaunged thi name þus
I wil be ded or ellis thou shalt die
Thou shalt not loue my lady Emelie
But I wil loue her only and no mo
For I am Palamon thi mortal fo
And þouȝ I haue no wepyn in þis place
But out of prison am stert be grace
That thou sholdist die of myn hond
For I defie thi swerd and thi brond
Whiche þat thou saist þᵗat I haue made to þe
What verrey fole þynk þat loue is fre
And I wil loue hire magre al thi myȝt
But for as muche as thow art a knyȝt
And woldist darrayn̄ here be bataille
Haue here my trowthe to morow I wil not faile
Withoute witinge of eny oþer wight
That here I wil be founden as A knyȝt
And bryngen harneis riȝt ynow for þe
And chees the beste ⁊and leve the worse for me
And mete ⁊and drynke þis nyȝt wil I brynge
Inow for the ⁊and clothis for thi beddynge
And yf so be þᵗat þou my lady wynne
And sle me in þis wode þat I am ynne
Thou maist wel haue thi lady as for me
This Palamon answerd I graunte it the
And þus þey be departid til amorow
Whanne either of ham haþ leid her feith to borov
Occupied out of all charite
O regne þᵗat woldist haue no felow wᵗith the
Ful soth is sad þat loue ne lordship̄
Wil not his thankes haue no feleship̄
We fynde that Arcite and Palamon
Arcite is riden anon into þe toun
And on the morow anon or it were liȝt
Ful pryueli two harneis he diȝt
Bothe sufficient ⁊and mete to arreigne
The bataille in the feld betwix ham tweyne
And on his hors alone as he was born̄
He caried the harneys him beforn̄
And in the grove at tyme ⁊and place set
This Arcite and þis Palamon̄ been met
To chaunge gan the colour in hisr his hir face
Riȝt as the hunters in regne ⁊and trace
That stondeth at the gappe wᵗith A spere
Whanne huntid is þe lioun ⁊and þe bere
And herith him come russhing in þe grevis
And brekith bothe bowez ⁊and eke levis
And thinkith here comyth my mortal enemy
Withoute faile he muste be ded or I
For either I moste sle him atte gappe
Or he muste sle me yf I myshappe
So ferden þey in chaunging of her͗ hue
As fer as ony of ham oþer knew
Ther nas no good day ne saluynge
But streiȝt withoute wordis of rehercyng
Euerich of ham helpith to arme oþer
As frendly as he were his owen broþer͗
And aftir þat with sharpe speris strong
They foynen ech at oþer longe
Thou myȝtist wene þat this Palamon
In his fiȝting were a lioun̄
And as a cruel tigre was Arcite
As wilde boris gan þey to geder͗ smyte
That freten whit as foom for Ire wood
Vp to þe angle fouȝte þey in her blood
And in this wise I lete ham fiȝting duelle
And forsoth I wil of Theseus telle
The destenye mynister general
That excusith in þe worlde ouyr al
The purueaunce þat god hath beforn
So straunge it is þᵗat þouȝ þe worlde had sworn
The contrary of a þing be ye or nay
Yet somtyme it shal falle vp on aday
That fallith not eft in a thousand yeer͗e
For certenly our appetitis here
Be it of pees hate warre or love
Al is rewlid be þe siȝte above
This mene I now be myȝti Theseus
That forto hunte is so desirous
And namely atte grete hert in May
That in his bed þer dawid him no day
That he nys glad and redy forto ride
With hunte and horn̄ ⁊and houndis be his side
For in his huntynge hath he such delit
That it is al his ioie ⁊and his appetit
To be him self þe grete hertis bane
For aftir Marcz he seruyth nov diane
Cleer was the day as I haue told or this
And Theseus with al ioie ⁊and blis
With his Ipolita þe faire quene
And Emely yclothid al in grene
An huntyng bith þey riden rially
And to þe groue þat stood þer fastby
In which þer was an hert as men him tolde
Duke Theseus þe streiȝt wey hath holde
And to þe launde he ridith ful riȝt
For þider was þe hert wont to haue his fliȝt
And ouer abrook and so forth on his way
The duke wolde haue a cours of him or twey
With houndis such as he list to comaunde
And whanne þis duke was come to þe launde
Vnder þe sonne he lokid ⁊and þat anon̄
He was waar of Arcite ⁊and Palamon̄
That fouȝten breme as it were bolis two
The briȝt suerdis wente to ⁊and fro
So hidously þat with þe leste strook
He semyd þat it wolde haue fellid on ook
But what þey were no þing he ne woot
This duke with his sporis his courser strook smote strook smote
And at a streit he was betwix ham two
And pullid out his swerde and saide ho
Nomore on peyne of lesing of your hed
Be myȝti marce anon ye shul be ded
That smytith eny strook þat I may se
But tellith me what myster men ye be
That bith so hardy to fiȝte here
Withoute Iuge or other officere
As thouȝ it were in listis rially
This Palamon̄ answerde hasteli
And saide sere what nedith wordis mo
We haue þe deth deserued bothe two
Two woful wrecchis be we ⁊and knyȝtis
That ben encombred of oure lyvis
And as thow art A riȝtful lord ⁊and Iuge
Ne yeve vs neither mercy ne refuge
But sle me first for saint charite
But sle my felow eke as wel as me
Or ellis him first for þey þᵘou knowe him lite
He is thi mortal fo þis is Arcite
That fro thi lond was banysshed on his hed
For which he hath serued to be ded
For this is he þᵗat cam to thi yate
And saide þᵗat he hiȝte Philostrate
Thus he iapith þe many a yeer
And thow hast maad him þi chief squyer
And þis is he þat loueth Emely
For sithnes þe day is come þat I shal dy
I make pleynli my confessioıı̄un
That I am þat woful palamoıı̄un
That hath thi prison broke wickedly
I am thi mortal fo and he am I
That loueth so hote Emely þe briȝt
That I wil dye here present in her siȝt
Therfore I axe deth of my Iewise
But sle my felow in the same wise
For bothe haue we deserued to be slayn
THis worthi duke answerd anon agayn̄
And saide this is a short conclusioıı̄un
Your owen mowth be your confessioıı̄un
Hath dampned you ⁊and I wil it recorde
Hit nedith not to peyne with þe corde
Ye shul be ded be myȝti mars the rede
Þe quene anon for verray wommanhede
Gan forto wepe and so dede Emelie
And alle the ladies in that companie
Gret pite was it as ham thouȝte alle
Þat evir such a chaunce sholde be falle
For gentilmen þey were and of gret astat
And no þing but for loue was þis debaat
And sawe hir blody woundis wide and sore
And alle criden bothe lasse and more
Haue mercy lord vpon vs wymmen alle
And on her bare knees doun þey falle
And wolde haue kild ham þere as þey stood
Til at þe laste slakid was his mood
For pite renneth sone in gentil herte
And þouȝ he first for ire quoke ⁊and sterte
He considered shortli in a clause
The trespas of ham bothe ⁊and eke þe cause
And al þogh þat his ire hire gilt acused
Ȝit in his reson he hem boþe excused
And þus he þouȝte wel þat euery man
Wil helpe him self in love al þat he can
And delyuer him self out of prisoıı̄un
And eke in his herte he hadde compassioıı̄un
Of wommen for þey were euer in one
And in his gentil herte he þouȝte anon̄e
And softe vnto him self he saide fy
Vpon a lord þat wil haue no mercy
But be a lioun bothe in word and dede
To ham þᵗat ben in repentaunce ⁊and drede
As wel as a proud dispitous man
That wil mayntene þat he first began
That lord hath litil of discressioıı̄un
That in such a caas can no diuisioıı̄un
But weyeth pride ⁊and humbles aftir one
And shortli whanne his ire is þus agon̄e
He gan to loke on hem wᵗith yen blake ⁊and blith
And spak thise wordis al on high
The god of loue A benedicite
How myȝti and how gret alord is he
Agayns his myȝt þer gayneth non obstakil
He may be clepid A god for his myrakil
For he can make at his owen gise
Of eueri herte as him list deuyse
Lo here þis Arcite ⁊and this Palamon̄
That queyntly were out of my prison̄
And myȝte a lyvid in thebes rially
And wyten I am her mortal enemy
And þat here deth lith in me also
And yet hath loue magre hir yen two
I brouȝt ham hithir bothe forto dye
div.note: noᵃta
div.l: Now lokith is not this an high folie
Who may be a fole but if þat he love
Behold for goddis sake that sittith above
Se how they blede be þey not wel araid
Thus hath her lord þe god of love ham paid
Her wages and her fees of her seruize
And yet þey wene forto be wise
That serue love for auȝt þat may falle
But this is yet þe beste game of alle
That she for whom þey haue this Iolite
Can ham þerfore as moche þank as me
She wot nomore of al þis hoot fare
Be god þan woot a Cuckow or an hare
But al moste be assaid hoot or cold
A man moste be A fool yong or olde
I woot it be my self ful longe agoon̄e
For in my tyme a seruaunt was I one
And þerfore sethnys I knowe of lovis peyne
And wot how sore þat can aman distreyne
As he þᵗat hath be cawȝt in this lase
I yow foryeue hoolli þis trespas
And at þe request of the quene þᵗat knelith here
And eke of Emeli my suster dere
And ye shul bothe vnto me swere
That neuer ye shal my croune dere
Ne make warre on me nyȝt ne day
But be my frendis in al that ye may
I yow foryeue this trespas eueridell
And þey him swar͗e his Axing eueridel
And him of lordship̄ and mercy praide
And he ham grauntid ⁊and þus he saide
TO speke of worthi lynage ⁊and richesse
Þouȝ þat she were a quene or A princesse
Ech of yow boþe is worthi doutlez
To wedde whan tyme is but nathelez
I speke as for my sustir Emely
For whom ye haue þis strif ⁊and þis Ielosy
Ye woot your self ye may not wedde two
At onys þeyȝ ye fiȝte euer mo
That one of you al be him loth or lef
He mot go pipe in an yvy lef
This is to say she may not haue bothe
Al be ye nevir so ielous and so loth̄e
And for thi I you put in this degre
That ech of you shal haue his destene
As him is shapin and herkyn in what wise
Lo here youre ende of þat y shal devise
Mi wil is this for plat conclusioıı̄un
Withoute eny replicacioıı̄un
Yf þat you likith take it for the beste
That euerich of you shal go where him list
Frely withoute daungerb or Raunson̄a daunger or Raunson̄ Raunson̄ or daunger
And þis day fifty wikes fer ne neer
Euerich of yow shal brynge an hundred knyȝtꝭis
Armed for listis vp alle riȝtis
Alredy to arreyne here be bateill
And þis behote I yow withoute fail
Vpon my trowthe and as I am trew knyȝt
That whethir of you bothe hath þᵗat myȝt
That is to sey whethir he or thow
May with his hundred as I spak of now
Sle his contrari or out of listis dryve
Him shal I yeue Emeli to wive
To whom þat fortune yeueth so fair a grace
The listis shal I make on þis place
And god so wisly on my sowle rewe
As I shal evene Iuge be and trewe
Ye shul non othir ende with me make
That one of you shal be ded or take
And if þe þynke þis is wel said
Saieth your avis and holde you paid
This is your ende and your conclusioıı̄un
Who lokith now liȝti but Palamoıı̄un
Who spryngeth vp for ioie but Arcite
Who coude telle or who coude endite
The ioie þat made is in this place
When Theseus hadde do so fair a grace
But doun on knees wente euery wiȝt
And thanked him with al her myȝt
And name þe Thebans ofte sithe
And þus with good hope and herte blithe
They take her leve and homward þey ride
To Thebes with olde wallis wide
I trowe men wolde it deme negligent
Ȝif I foryete to telle the entent
Of Theseus that goth so besili
To make vp the listis rialli
That such an nobil entre as it was
I dar wel say in this worlde þer nas
The circuyt a myle ther of was abowte
Wallid with stoon and diched round aboute
Round was the shapthe in maner of A compas
Ful of degrees the highest of sixti paas
That whan aman was set in on degre
He lettit not his felow forto se
Estward ther was a gate of marbil whit
Westward such anoþer appositit
And shortli to conclude such a place
Was non in erthe in so litil space
For in þe lond ther was no craftis man
That gemetrie or ars metric can
Ne porteture ne kervar of Images
That Theseus ne yaf mete drynke ⁊and wages
The entre forto make and deuyse
And forto do his riȝt and his sacrifize
He Estward hath vp on þe gate above
In worship̄ of Venus goddesse of love
div.note: ¶ Venus
div.l: Do make an Awter and an Oratory
And of the westward in memorie
Of Marce hath he maad such anothir
div.note: ¶ Mars
div.l: That coste large of gold a fothir
And northward in a tour of þe wal
Of whit Alabastre and reed coral
An Oratori riche forto se
In worship̄ of diane goddesse of chastite
div.note: ¶ Diana
div.l: Hath Theseus do wrouȝt in nobil wise
But yet hadde I foryete to deuyse
The nobill karvynge ⁊and þe portreturis
The shapthe þe contenaunce ⁊and the figuris
That weren in the Oratories thre
First in þe tempil of venus þᵘou maist se
Wrouȝt in þe wall ful petousli to be holde
The brokyn slepis and þe sighis colde
The sacrid teris and þe weymentynge
The firi strokis and þe desiringe
That loves folkes in þis worlde enduryn
The othes be her couenauntis Assuren
Plesaunce . hope desire and fool hardinesse
Beaute and yowthe . baudry and richesse
Charmys and sorcerie . lesinges ⁊and flaterie
Dispence besinesse and Ielowsie
That wered of yelow goldꝭes a garlond
And A Cuckow sittyng i on her hond
Feestis instrumentis carollis and daunsis
Lust . and aray . and alle þe circumstauncis
Of love with þat I rekene and shal
Be ordir were peynted on þe wall
And mo þanne I can make mencioıı̄un
For sothli al þe mounte of sitheroıı̄un
There Venus hath hir principal dwellyng
Was shewd on þe wal here portreyyng
With al þe ioie ⁊and al þe lustinesse
Nouȝt was foryeten þe Porters idelnesse
Ne Narcrisus þe faire yore agoon̄
Ne yet þe folie of kyng Salamon
The enchauntement of Medea ⁊and hardynesse

div.l: Ne of turnus with his hard fire corage
The riche Cresus caitifs in servage
Thus may ye se þat wisdom ne riches
Beaute sleyȝte strengthe ne hardinesse
Ne may with venus holde champartie
For as she lust þe worlde may she gye
So alle thise folk cauȝt were in her lase
Til þey for wo ful ofte saide allas
Suffiseth þise ensamplis . one or two
And thowgh I coude rekene A thousand mo
The statu of venus glorios forto se
Was maad fletynge in þe large se
And fro the navil doun she was
With wawis briȝt as eny glas
A cotel in hir riȝt hond hadde she
And on her hed ful semeli on to se
A Rose garlond fressh and wel smellynge
Above her . dowfis fleyng
Beforn hir stood her sone cupido
Vpon his shuldris wyngis hadde two
And blynd he was as it is ofte seen
A bowe he baar and arowes cleen
Whi sholde I not eke telle þe wall
The portreyynge þat was on al
Wᵗithyn þe tempil of myȝti mars þe Rede
Al was peynted þe wallis in lengthe ⁊and brede
Like to the Estris of þe grisly place
That hiȝt þe grete tempil of mars in trace
In that cold northeryn northeryn frosty regioun̄
There as mars hath his souereȳn mansioıı̄un
First on the wal was peyntid a forest
In whiche þer dwellith neither man ne best
With knotty ⁊and knarry bareyn treys olde
Of stubbis sharp̄ ⁊and hidous to beholde
In which ran as wymbil in a swolow
As thouȝ it a storm were sholde brest eủery bow
And downward on an hil vnder a bent
There stood the tempil of marce armipotent
Wrouȝt al of burnyd steel þᵉ which þe entre
Was longh and streiȝt ⁊and gladly forto se
And ther out cam a Rage ⁊and such a voyss
That it made al þe gatis forto reyse
The northeren light yn at þe dore shon̄
For wyndow on the wal was þer non̄
Thurgh which men myȝte eny liȝt disserne
The doris were al Athemaundis eterne
Iclenchit overthwart ⁊and endlonge
With Iren forto make it strong
Euery piler þe tempil forto susteyne
Was tonne greet of yren briȝt ⁊and shene
There saw I first þe derk ymagenyng
Of felony and al þe compassing
The cruel ire reed as eny glede
The pike purs and eke the pale rede
The smyler wᵗith þe knyf vnder the cloke
The shepen brennyng with þe blak smoke
The treson of the murdryng in the bed
The opyn werris with woundis alle bled
Contak with blody knyf and sharp̄ manace
Al ful of chirkyng was the sory place
The sleer of him yet saw I there
His herte blood hath batid al his chere
The nail I dryve in þe shode an highte
The colde deth wᵗith mouth gapynge vp riȝt
A myddil of the tempil sat myschaunce
With discomfort ⁊and sory contenaunce
Yet saw I woodnesse lawghyng in his rage
The hunte strangled with þe wilde boris corage
The sowe fretyng þe child in þe cradil
The cook yscalded for his longe ladil
Nouȝt foryetyn was þe infortune of Marte
The carter ouer riden wᵗith his owen k arte k karte
Vnder þe wheel ful lowe he lay adoun
There were also of martirs deuocioun̄
The barbour þe botcher and the smyth
That forged sharpe swerdis in þe stith
And al aboue depeynted in a tour
The high conquest sittinge in gret honour͗
With þe sharp swerd ouer his hed
Hangynge be a subtil twyned thred
Depeynted was þere þe slawȝtir of Iuliꝰus
Of grete Nero and of Antonius
Al be þat tyme þey were vnborn̄
Yet was her deth peynted þere beforn̄
Be manassynge of Marce riȝt be figure
So was it shewd riȝt be portreture
As it is depaynted in the serclis above
Who shal be sleyn or ded for love
Suffizeth on ensampil in stories olde
I may not rekene alle þouȝ I wolde
The statu of Marce vp on a carte stood
Armyd and lokyd grym as he were wood
And over his hed þer shynen two figu y ris figuys figuris
That one puella hight hight þat othir Iubius
This god of armys was araid þus
A wolf þer stood beforn him at his feet
With yen rede ⁊and of aman he eet
With subtile pensel was peyntid his story
In redowndynge of Marce ⁊and of his glory
Now to þe tempil of diane the chaste
As shortli as I can I wil me haste
To telle yow al þe descripcioıı̄un
Depeyntid on the wallis vp and doun
Of huntynge ⁊and of shamefast chastite
There saw I how woful Calistope
Whanne þᵗat diane grevid was wᵗith here
Was turned fro womman in to a bere
And aftir was she maad the lood sterre
Thus was it peynted I can say no ferre
Her sone is eke a sterre as men may se
There saw I Diane turned vntil a tre
I mene not the goddesse Diane
But Peneus douȝter which þᵗat hiȝte Diane
There saw I Atheon an hert Imakid
For vengeaunce þat he saw Diane al nakid
I saw how þᵗat houndis haue him cauȝt
And fretyn him for þᵗat þey knew him nouȝt
Yet Ipeynted Ipeyned Ipeynted was a litil furthermore
How Artalaunce huntid þe wilde bore
And meliager and meny other mo
For whiche Diane wrouȝte him care ⁊and wo
There saw I many another wonder story
The whiche me list not drawe in memory
This goddesse on an hert high is set
With smale houndis abowte her feet
And vnder nethe hir feet she hadde a mone
Wexynge it was and sholde wany sone
In gawdy grene her statu clothed was
With bowe in hond ⁊and arow in caas
Here yen cast she ful lowe adoun̄
There pluto hath his derk Regioun̄
A womman trauelynge was here beforn̄
But for hir child so longe was vnborn̄
Ful pitousli lucyna gan she calle
And saide help for thou maist best of alle
Wel coude he peynte lyueli þat it wrouȝte
With meny a floreyn he þise huwis bouȝte
NOw ben thise listis maad ⁊and theseus
That at his grete cost hath araid þus
The templis ⁊and þe auters eueridel
Whanne it was don̄ it likid him wel
But stynte I wil of Theseus alite
And speke of Palamon ⁊and of Arcite
The day approchith in here attourneyynge
That euerich sholde an hundrid knyȝtꝭes brynge
The bateille to arreyn̄ as I you tolde
And til Theseus here couenaunt forto holde
Hath euerich of ham brouȝt an hundrid knyȝtꝭis
Wel Iarmed for þe werre at al riȝtis
And sikirli þertrowed many aman
That nevir sithnes the worlde began
As forto speke of knyȝthood of her hond
As fer as god hath made se ⁊and lond
Nas of so fewe so nobil acompany
For euery wiȝt that loued chiualrie
And wolde his thankis haue passing name
He praide that he myȝte be of þat game
And wel was him that þerto chosyn was
For yf þer fil to morow such a caas
Ye knowe wel that eueri lusty knyȝt
That loueth paramouris ⁊and hath his myȝt
Were it in yngelond or ellis where
They wolde her thankis willen to be there
The fiȝt for alady benedicite
Hit were A lusty siȝte forto se
And riȝt so ferthe þay wᵗith Palamon̄
With him þer wente knyȝtis many on̄
Some wel be armed in habergeon̄
Some in brest plate ⁊and in briȝt gippon̄
And some wol haue a peir͗e of platis large
And some wolde haue pris sheldis ⁊and targe
Some wolde be Armed on his leggis wele
And haue an ax ⁊and amace of steel
Ther is no newe gise but it was hold
Armed were þey as I haue tolde
Euerich aftir his owen oppinion̄
There maist þow se comyng wᵗith palamon̄
Bigurge him self þe king of trace
Blak was his berd ⁊and manli was his face
The cerclis in his yen in hes hed
They glowden̄ betwix yelow ⁊and reed
And like a griffyn̄ loked he aboute
With kempd heris in his browis stoute
His lemys grete his brawnys hard ⁊and strong
His shuldrez brode . his harneys round ⁊and long
And as þe gise was in his contre
Ful high vp on a chare of gold stood he
With four white bolis in þe trace
In stede of Cotearmure in his harnase
With nailis yelow ⁊and briȝt as eny golde
He hadde A bere skyn̄ cool blak for olde
His longe heris were kempt behynd his bak
As eny rauen fethir it shoon̄ for blak
A wrethe of gold . arme greet of huge weyȝte

Marce hath his wil þᵉ knyȝt hath his bone
And be my hood þou shalt be esed sone
The trompours with þe lowd mynstralsie
The heroudis þat ful lowde hole and crie
Bene in her ioie for þe wel of Dane Arcite
But herkeneth me and styntith alite
Which A myrakil þer befil anone
This ferce Arcite hath his helm of done
And on a courser forto shewe his face
He priked endlong þe large place
Lokyng vpward vp on this Emelie
And she agayn him cast a frendly ye
For wommen forto speke of comune
The folow al þe faver of fortune
And was al in his chere as in his hert
Out of þe ground A fire infernal stert
From pluto sent atte request of satourne
For which his hors for feer gan to tourne
And lepte Aside and foundrid as he lepe
And or þat Arcite may take kepe
He piȝte him on þe pomel of his hed
Þat in þe place he lay as he were ded
His brest to brosten with his sadil bowe
As blak he lay as eny cole or crowe
So was þe blood ronne in his face
Anon he was born̄ out of the place
With herte sore to Theseus paleys
Tho was he corvyn̄ out of his harneys
And in a bed brouȝt ful feire and blyue
For he was yet in memory and alyve
And alwey cryynge aftir Emely
Duke Theseus with al his company
Is come hom to Attenes his cite
With al blis and gret solempnite
Al be it that his auenture was falle
He nolde not discomforte hem alle
Men saide eke þat Arcite sholde not dy
He sholde be helid of his maladye
And of another þing þey were feyn̄
That of hem alle þer was non sleyn̄
Alle were þey sore hurt ⁊and namely one
That with a spere wᵗith thrilled þoruȝ þe brestbon̄
The othir woundis and þe broke bonys
Some hadde saluys and some hadde charmys
Fermaces of herbes and eke save
They dronkyn for þey wolde her lyves save
For whiche þis nobil duke as he wel can
Comforteth and honoureth euery man
And made revell al the longe nyȝt
Vnto the straunge lordis as it was riȝt
Ne þere was holden no discomfitynge
But as a Iustez or a turmetynge
For sothli þer was no descomfiture
For fayling nys but auenture
Ne to be lad be force vnto þe stake
Vn yeldyn and with twenty knyȝtis take
On ꝑpersone alone with oute mo
And haried forth be arme foot and to
And eke his stede dryven forth wᵗith stavis
With footmen bothe yemen and knavis
Hit was arekened him no velony
Ther may noman clepe it a cowardrie
For which anon duke Theseus let crie
To styntyn al rancour and enuye
Þe degre as wel in o side as in oþer
And eythir side lik as othir brother
And yaf ham yiftis aftir her degre
And fulli held a feste dayes thre
And conveied þe knyȝtis worthily
Out of his town a iourney largely
And hom wente euery man þe riȝte way
Ther was no more but farwel haue good day
But forto speke of Palamon ⁊and Arcite
OfPalamon wil I stynte Alite
But swellith the brest of Arcite ⁊and þe sore
Encresith at his hert . more and more
The cloterid blood for ony lechecraft
Coruptith and in his bowk is laft
That neither veynblood ne ventosynge
Ne drinke of herbis may be his helpynge
The vertu epulsif or anymall
Fro þat vertu Iclepid naturall
Ne may þe venym voide ne expelle
The pipis ⁊and his lungis gan to swelle
And euer lacert in his brest adoun̄
He is shent with venem and corupcioıı̄un
Hym gayneth neyþer forto gete his lif
Voideth vpward and dounward laxatif
Al is to brosten þat regioun̄
Nature hath no dominacioıı̄un
And certeynli þer nature wol not worche
Fare wel fesik . go bere þe man to chirche
This is al and som Arcite moste dye
For which he sendith aftir Emelie
And Palamon that was his cosyn dere
Than saide he þus as ye shul aftir here
Now may þe woful spirit in my hert
Declare a poynt of alle my sorowis smert
To you my lady þat I loue most
Riȝt þus bequede y þe . þe seruize of my gost
To yow abouen euery creature
Sithnes þat my lif may no lenger dure
Alas þe peyne . alas þe wo strong
That I for you haue suffrid and so long
Alas þe deth . alas my Emelie
Allas þe departing of our companye
Alas my hertis quene . alas my lif
Mi hertes lady . ender of my lif
What is þe worlde what axith men to haue
Now with his loue now in his cold graue
Alone withouten eny company
Fare wel my swete fo my Emelie
And softe take me in your Armez tweye
For þe loue of god and herkenyth what I say
I haue here wᵗith my cosyn Palamon̄
Had strif and Rancour many aday agoon̄
For þe loue of yow . and of my ielowsie
And Iupiter so wisli my soule gye
As in this worlde riȝt now knowe I non̄
So worthi to be loued as Palamon̄
To serue you and wil do al his lif
And if þat ever ye shul be a wiff
Foryetith not þe gentil Palamon̄
And with þat word his speche was ny agon̄
For fro his feet vnto his brest was com
The cold of deth þat hath him ouercom̄
And yet more ouer for in his Armes two
The vital strenghthe is lost and al Ago
Saue onli þe intellectis withouten more
That duellith in his herte sik and sore
Gan faile whanne þe herte felith deth
Dusshid his yen to . and failith his breth
But on his lady yet caste he his ye
His laste word was mercy Emelie
His spirit chaungith þe hous ⁊and wente þere
As I cam never I can not telle where
There y stynte I am no deuynestre
Of soulis fynde I not in þis registre
Ne me ne list þe oppinions telle
Though y write myȝte ⁊and fynd where þey dwelle
Now wil I speke forth of Emelie
Now wepith Emely ⁊and wailith Palamon̄
And Theseus his sustir toke anon̄
Swownynge ⁊and bare hir fro þe cors away
What helpith it to tary forth þe day
To telle how she weep bothe eue and morow
For in such caas wommen haue such sorow
Whanne þat her͗ husbondis be frōm hem ago
That for þe more part þey sorowen so
Or ellis falle in such A maladie
That at þe laste certaynli þey die
Infynit ben þe sorowis and þe teris
Of olde folk and folk of tendre yeris
In al þe toun for deth of þis theban
For him þer wepith bothe child ⁊and man
So greet wepynge was þer non certayn
Whan Ector was brouȝt al fresh Islayn̄
To troie allas þe pete þat was þere
Cracchynge of chekis rentynge of here
Whi woldest thow be ded þis wymmen crie
And haddest gold ynough and Emelie
No man myȝte gladde Theseus
Savynge his olde fader Egeus
That knew þis worldis transmutacioıı̄un
As he hadde seyn it vp and doun
Ioye aftir woo and wo aftir gladnesse
And shewde him ensaumple ⁊and liknesse
Riȝt as þer deide never man quod he
That he ne loued in erthe in som degre
Riȝt so þer lyved neuer man he saide
In al þis worlde þat som tyme he deide
This worlde is but a thorow fare ful of wo
And we be pilgrymes passinge to and fro
Deth is an ende of eueri worldis sore
And ouer al þis ȝet saide he mykil more
To þis effect ful viseli to enhorte
The pepil þat þey sholde hem recomforte
Duke Theseus with al his besi cure
Caste now where þe sepulture
Of good Arcite may best Imakid be
And eke most honurably in his degre
And at þe laste he took conclusion̄
That þere as first Arcite and palamon̄
Hadde for loue bataille ham between̄
That in þat selue grove swete and green̄
There as he hadde his amerous desiris
His complaynt . and for love his hote feris
He wolde make A fire in þe whiche þe office
Funeral he myȝte fully complice
And leet anon to hacke and to hewe
The okis olde . and ley ham on A Rewe
In culpuns wel araid forto brenne

div.l: His officers wᵗith swyft feet þey renne
And riden anon at his commaundement
And aftir þis Theseus hath sent
Aftir a beere . and he it ouer sprad
With clothis of gold þe richest þᵗat he had
And of þe same he clothid Arcite
Vpon his hondis his glovis white
And on his hed a croune of laurer grene
And in his hond a swerd ful briȝt ⁊and shene
He laide him bare the visage on þe bere
Ther with he wepte þat pite was to here
And for þe pepil sholde se him alle
Whan it was day . he brouȝt him into þᵉ halle
That þorouȝ þe cryynge ⁊and þe sown
Tho cam þis woful theban Palamoun
With floterid berd . and ruggid Asshi heris
In clothis blak ydroppid al with teris
And passinge oþer of weping Emely
The rewfullest of al þe company
In as muche the seruize shuld be
The more nobil and riche in his degre
Duke Theseus . leet thre stedis forth brynge
That trappid were in steel al gliterynge
And couered with þe armys of Arcite
Vp on þe stedis grete and white
Ther satyn folk . of whiche on bare his sheld
Anothir a spere vpon . his hondis held
The thridde baar him with him his bowe tᵘurkeys
Of brend gold was þe caas ⁊and þe Arowes
And riden forth a pa pa paas wᵗith sorouful chere
Toward þe grove as ye shul aftir here
With slak face and yen rede and weet
Thorow out þe cite be þe maistir strete
That spred was al with blac wonder hy
Riȝt of þe same is the strete Iwrye
Op on the riȝt hond wente olde Egeus
And on þat othir side duke Theseus
With vesselis of gold in hir hond ful fyne
And ful of hony . mylk . blood and wyne
Eke Palamoun wᵗith ful greet compane
And aftir þat com woful Emele
With fire in hond as was þat tyme þᵉ gise
div.note: Ritus
div.l: To do þe office and þe funeral seruize
High labour and ful greet apparelyng
Was at þe seruize of þat fire makynge
That with his grene top þe heuen rauȝte
And xxᵗⁱ fadom of brede þe armys strauȝt
This is to say þe bowes were so brood
Of straw . first was layd meny a lood
But how the fire was made vp an heyȝte
And as to telle yow what þe treys hiȝte
As oke . firre . birch . Ash . Alder holym popeler
Mapil thorn . bech . aspe . box chesteyn lynd . laurer
Wilow . elme . plane hasil wipultre
How þey were fellid shal not be told for me
Ne how þe goddis rennyn vp and doun
Disherited of þeyr habitacioıı̄un
In whiche þey woned in reste and pees
Nymphes . founus and Amarides
Ne hou the bestis . and the briddes alle
Fillen for feer whanne the wode gan falle
Ne how þe ground agast was of þe liȝt
That was not wont to se þe sonne briȝt
Ne hou þe fire was cowchid first wᵗith stre
And þanne wᵗith drye stickis cloven on thre
And þanne wᵗith grene wode and spicery
And þanne with cloth of gold made wᵗith perry
And garlondis hangynge wᵗith many a flour
The myrre the encence with swete odour
Ne hou Arcite lay among al þis
Ne what richesse abowte his body is
Ne hou þat Emele as was the gise
Put in the fire funeral seruize
Ne hou she swowned whan made was þᵉ fire
Ne what she spak ne what was her desire
Ne what iewellis . men in to þe fire caste
Whan þᵗat þe fire was gret ⁊and brende faste
Ne hou som caste her shelde ⁊and som her spere
And of her vestimentis which þᵗat þey were
And cuppis ful of mylk wyne and blood
In to þe fire þat brent as it were wood
Ne hou the grekis with an huge route
Thries . riden al þe fire aboute
Op on the lift hond wᵗith an high showtynge
And thriez with here speris claterynge
And thrijs how the ladies gan crie
Ne how that led was homward Emelie
Ne Arcite is brent to Asshen cold
Ne how the lich wakis was yhold
That ilke nyȝt . ne how grekis pley
The wake pleies kepe I not to seye
Which wrastelith best naked wᵗith oil anoynted
Ne who þat bare him best at þe poynt
I wil not telle al how þey goon̄
Hom to Atenes when þe pley is don̄
But shortli to þe poynt þan wol I wende
To make of my long tale an ende
BE proces . and be lengthe of certeyn yeris
Al stynt is þe mornynge ⁊and þe teris
Of grekis . be on general assent
Than semyth me þere was A parlement
At Attenes vpon certeyn̄ poynt and caas
And among the which poyntis spokyn was
To haue with certayn contrees alyaunce
And haue fulli of Thebes obeissaunce
For which þis nobil theseus anon
Leet sende aftir gentil Palamon
Vnwist of him what was þe cause and whi
But in his blake clothis sorowfulli
He cam at his commaundement an hi
Tho sent Theseus for Emely
Whan þey were set and pees was al þᵉ place
And Theseus abiden hath a space
Or eny word cam from his wise brest
His yen he cast þere as him list
And with a sad visage he sighed stille
And aftir þat riȝt þus he saide his wille
The firste mouer of þe cause Above
Whan he first made þe cheyne of love
Greet was the effect and hyȝ was þe entent
Wel wiste he whi and what þer of he ment
For with þat fair cheyne of love he bond
The fire . þe eyr͗e the watir and the lond
In certeyn bondis that may not fle
The same prince ⁊and þe same mever ꝙquod he
Hath stabled in this wrecchid worle adoun
Certayn dayes . and duracioıı̄un
To al þat is engendrid in this place
Ouer þe whiche day . þey mow not pace
Al mowe þey yet the daiez Abrigge
Þer nedith non acutorite to legge
For it is preued be experience
But þat me list . to declare my sentence
Than may wel men be this ordre discerne
That ilke mever stabil is . and eterne
Wel may men knowe but it be a fool
That euery parti darreyuid fro his hool
For nature hath not take his begynnyng
Of no part . or of cantel of A thyng
But of a þyng that parfit is and stable
Descendyng so . til it be corumpabil
And þerfore for his wise purueaunce
He hath so wel be set his ordenaunce
Þat specifieth of thingis and progressions
Sholden endure be successions
And nouȝt etern̄ withoute ony lye
This maist thou vnderstonde and se At ye
Lo . the ook . þat hath so long Anorisshyng
Fro þe tyme þat he begynneth to sprynge
And hath so long lif . as ye may se
Ȝit at the laste wastid is þe tre
Considereth how þat the hard stoon̄
Vnder our feet / on whiche we trede and goon̄
Ȝit wastith it as it lith be the wey
The brood ryver sumtyme wexit drey
The grete townes se we wane and wende
Thanne ye se that al þing hath an ende
Of man of womman se we also
That nedith in one of þe termys two
This is to say in youthe or ellis in age
He moot be ded þe king as shal a kna page
Som in his bed . som in the depe se
Som in the large feld as ye may se
Ther helpith nouȝt . þat gon þat ilke way
Than may I say al þing mot dey
What makith þis but Iubiter þe kyng
That is prince and cause of al þing
Conuertynge vs alle vnto his propre wil
For which it is arreyued soth to tel
And her agayns no creature alyve
Of no degre availeth forto stryve
Than is it wisdom as thynketh me
To make vertu of necessite
And take it whilis . we may not it eschewe
And thynketh . þat to vs alle it is due
And who so grucchith he doth folie
And rebel is to him þat al may gye
And / certeinly aman hath most honour
To dien in his most excellent flour
Whan he is sikir of his good name
Þat hath he do his frend no harm ne shame
And gladder may his frend be of his deth
Whan with honour so vp yolden is his breth
Thanne whanne his name apallid is for Age
For al foryeten is his vasselage
Than is his best as for a worthi fame
To dien whan he is best of name
The contrary eke for al his wilfulnesse
Whi grucche we . whi haue we heuynesse
That gode Arcite of chiualrie the flour
Departid is with duete and honour
Out of þis foule prison of this lif
Whi grucchith his cosyn and his wif
Of his welfare that loueth him so wel
Can he ham thanke nay god woot never adel
Þat bothe his soule . and eke him offende
And yet they mowe her lustis not amende
What shal I conclude of this longe story
But aftir wo I rede vs be mery
And thonke Iubiter of al his grace
And er we departen from þis place
I rede we of sorowis two
O parfit ioie lastyng . ever mo
And loketh now where most sorow is here yn
There wil I first amende and begynne
Sustir quod he þis is my ful assent
With al þe auyse of my parlement
That gentil Palamon your owen knyȝt
That serueth you with herte and myȝt
And euer hath do . syn ye first him knew
That ye shul of your grace on him rewe
And take him for husbond and lord
Lene me your hond for þis is our accord
Let se now of your wommanli pite
He is a kyngis sonez brother parde
And thowȝ he were a poer bacheler
Syn he hath serued you so meny ayeer
And hadde for you so greet aduersite
It mot be considered levith me

div.l: (base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
¶ Here endith þe knyȝhtꝭes tale .
And begynneth the Milleris prologe
Whanne. þat the knyȝt had þus his tale told
In al þe companie nas þer yong ne old
That he ne saide it was a nobil story
And worthi to be drawe in memory
And nameli þe gentilis euerichon
Our . ost . lowgh . and swoor so mot I . goon
This vnbokelid is the male
Let se now . who shal telle anoþer tale
For trewli the game is wel begonne
Now telle ye sir monk if þat ye konne
Som what to quyte with þe knyȝt his tale
The Milward þat fordronkyn was al pale
So þat vnnethis vpon his hors he sat
He nolde avale noþer hood ne hat
Ne abide noman for his curtesie
But in Pilatis vois he gan crie
And swoor be armys . blood and bonys
I can An nobil tale forthe nonys
Þe whiche I wol now quyte the knyȝt his tale
Our ost saw þat he was dronke of ale
And saide abide Robin leue brothir
Sum bettir man shal telle first Anothir
Abide let vs worke thriftely
Be cokkis soule quod he that nyl not I
For I wil speke . or ellis . go my wey
Our ost answerd telon adeuel wey
Thou art a fool thi wit is ouercom
Now herkeneth ꝙquod þe myllere alle and som
But first I make A protestaciou
That I am dronke I knowe be my soun
And therfore yf I awȝt mys speke or say
Wite it þe Ale of Suthwerk I you pray
For I wol telle A legende and a lif
Bothe of A Carpenter and of his wif
How þᵗat þe clerk . hath set þe wriȝtis cappe
The reve answerd and saide stynt þi clappe
Let be thi lewd dronkyn harlottrie
Hit is synne and eke greet folie
To appeire ony man or him defame
And eke brynge wivis in such a name
Thow maist I nowgh of oþer thyngis sayn
This dronken Milward spak ful sone Agayn
And saide leve brothir Oswold
Who hath no wif he is no cokewolde
But I say not þerfore þat thow art on
Ther bith gode wyvis many on
Whi art þou angri with my tale now
I haue a wiff parde as wel as thow
Yet nolde I not for þe oxen in my plow
Take vp on me more thanne ynow
And deme of my self that y were on
I wolbeleve that I am non .
An husbond . sholde not be inquisitif
Of goddis priuitees ne of his wiff .
So he may fynde goddis fuson þere
Of the . remenaunt nedith not to enquere ¶
What sholde I more say but this Millere
He nolde his word for noman forbere
But tolde his chorlis tale in his manere
Me ouer thynketh þat I shal reherce it here
And þerfore euery gentil wight I pray
Demeth not for goddis loue þat I say
Not for evil entent . but þat I moste reherce
Here talis . al be þey bett̉er or wers
Or ellis fulsen som of my matere
And þerfore who so listith not to here
Turne ouer þe leef . and chees another tale
For he shal fynde ynowe bothe grete ⁊and smale
Of historial þing þat towchith gentilnesse
And eke moralite . and holynesse
Blameth not me if þat ye chese amys
The myllere is a chorle þe know wel this
So was the Reve . and eke othir mo
And harlottrie þey tolde bothe two
Avisith you and put me out of blame
And eke men shul not make ernest of game
Here begynneth the Milleres tale
WHilom þ̉erwas dwellyng in Oxenforde
A riche chuf that gestis hadde to borde
And of his craft he . was a Carpenter
Wᵗith him þer was duellynge A poer scoler
Hadde lernyd Art but al his fantasie
Was turnyd for to lerne Astrologie
And coude a certeyn of conclusions
To demyn bi interogacions
If þat men axed him certayn houris
Or yf þat men axed him what sholde befalle
Of euery thing . I . may not rekene alle
This clerk was clepid hende Nicholas
Of dern loue he coude . and of solas
And therto he was sly and ful pryuy
And lik amaiden meke forto se
A chambir hadde he in þat ostelrie
Alone withoute eny companye
Ful fetosli y diȝt with herbis sote
And he him self was swete as is þe rote
Of licorice or of eny Cetewale
His Almegeste his bokis grete and smale
His astrology . longinge for his art
His Awgrym stones lay feire apart
On shelvis cowchid at his beddis hed
His presse ycouered with a folding reed
And al aboue þer lay agay sawtre
On whiche he made anyȝtis melode
So swete þat al þe chambir rong
And Angelus ad virginem he song
And aftir þat he song þe kyngis note
Ful often blissid was his mery throte
And þus þis swete clerk his tyme spent
Aftir his sendinge and his rent
