Vnder an hethen castel at þe laste
The whiche þe name not in my tixt I fynde
Custaunce ⁊and eke hir child vp cast
Almyȝti god þat saveth alman kynde
Haue on Custaunce ⁊and her child sum mynde
That fallen is in hethen lond eftsone
In poynt to spille as I shal telle you sone
Doun from þe Castel comyth þer many a wiȝt
To gauryn on þis ship ⁊and on Custaunce
But shortli fro þe Castel on anyȝt
The lordis Steward god ȝif him myschaunce
A theef þat hadde reyued our creaunce
Com in to þe ship alone ⁊and saide hou she sholde
His lemman be wheþ̉er she wolde or nolde ¶
Tho was this wrecchid womman wo be gon
Her child cride and she pitousli
But blissed mari helpt her anon
For with her strogelyng wel ⁊and merili
The theef fil over þe bord al sodenly
And in þe se he dreynt for vengeaunce
And thus hath crist vnwemmyd kept Custᵃunce
O foul lust of luxurie lo thyn ende
Not onli þat thou feyntist mannys mynde
But verili þou wolt his body shende
Thenne of thi werk and thi lustis blynde
Is compleynynge hou meny on may men fynde
That nouȝt for werk sumtyme but fol entent
To do this synne be othir sleyn or shent
Hou may þis week womman haue þe strengthe
Here to defende ayens the renegat
O golias vnmesurable of lengthe
How myȝti Dauid made þe so mate
So yong of armure and so desolate
How durste he loke vp on thi face
Wel may men seen it is but goddis grace
Who yaf Iudith corage or hardinesse
To sle Olofernes in his tent
And to delyueren out of wrecchidnesse
The pepil of god I say to þis entent
That riȝt as god spirit and vigour sent
To hem and saued out of myschaunce
He sente strengthe ⁊and vigour vnto Custaunce
Forth goth her ship þorow out þe narov mouth
Of Iubiter ⁊and sept̉er Dryvyng ay
Som tyme west ⁊and som tyme north ⁊and south
And somtyme est ful meny a wery wey
Til cristis moder I blissid be she ay
Hath shapen þorow her endlees goodnesse
To make an ende of al her hevynesse ¶
Now lete vs stynte of Custaunce but a throw
And speke of Romayn þe Emperour
That out of Rome hath be lettris know
The slauȝter of cristen folk ⁊and dishonour
Doon vnto his douȝter be a fals traitour
I mene þe cursid ⁊and wickid sowdonnesse
That at þe feste leet sle moboþemo boþe more ⁊and lesse
For which þis emꝑperour hath sent anon
His senatour with rial ordenaunce
And othir lordis god woot meny on
On surreyns to take hiȝ vengeaunce
They brenne ⁊and sle and bryngith he to myschᵃunce
Ful meny aday but shortly þis is þe ende
Homward to Rome þey shapen hem to wende
This senatour repairith with victori
To Romeward sailing ful rially
And mette þe ship as saith þe stori
In whiche Custaunce sit ful pitousli
No þing knew he what she was ne whi
She was in such aray þᵗat she ne wol sey
Of here astat þouȝ she sholde die
He bryngith hir to Rome to his wiff
He yaf her to here ⁊and her yong sone also
And wᵗith þe cenatour ladde hir lif
Thus can our ladi brynge out of wo
Woful Custaunce ⁊and many another mo
And longe tyme duellid she in þat place
In holi workis euer was her grace
The senatours wif hir aunte was
But for al þᵗat she knew him nevir þe more
I wil no lenger tarie in this caas
But to kyng Alla which I spak of yore
I wol retourne ⁊and lete I wol Custaunce
Vnder þe senatours gouernaunce
Kyng Alla which þᵗat hadde his moder slayn ¶
Vponaday fil in such repentaunce
And if I shortli telle shal and pleyn
To Rome he cometh and receyueth his penᵃnce
And put him in þe Popis ordenaunce
In hiȝ and lowȝ and iesus crist besouȝte
Foryeue him his wickid workꝭes þᵗat he had wrouȝt
The fame anon þorouȝ Rome is born
How Alla kyng shal come a pilgremage
By herbegeours þat wenten him beforn
For whiche þe senatours as was þe vsage
Rood him ayens ⁊and many of his lynage
As wel to shewen his magnificence
As to doon eny kkyngk kyng reuerence
Gret chere doth þis nobil senatour
To kyng Alla⁊and he to him also
Eueri of hem doth to other gret honour
And so be fil þat on aday or two
This senatour is to kyng Alla go
To feste shortly ⁊and I shal not ly
Custaunces sone wente in his company
Sum men wolde say at þe request of Custaunce
This senatour hadde led þis child to feste
I may not telle eueri circumstaunce
Be as be may þere was he at þe leste
But soth it is riȝt at his moder heste
Beforn Alla duryng þe mete space
The child stood lokyng in þe kyngꝭes face
Alla þe kyng of þis child hath gret wonder
And to þe senatour he saide anone
Whose is þis faire child þᵗat stondith yonder
I not qd he be god ⁊and be saint Iohn
A moder he hath but fader hath he noon
That I of woot and shortli in a stounde
He tolde Alla how þe child was founde
But god woot quod þis senatour also ¶
So vertuos a lyver in my lif
Ne saw I never ne herde of mo
Of wordly wymmen maiden widov or wiff
I dar wel say she hadde leuer wᵗith a knyf her stike
Thorow out her brest þan be a woman wike
Ther is noman coude brynge hir to þe prik
Now was this child as lik vnto Custaunce
As possible is a creature forto be
This Alla hath þe face in Remembraunce
Of dame Custaunce⁊and þeron musid he
Yf þat þe childis moder were auȝt she
That is his wiff ⁊and pryueli he siȝte
And spedde him fro þe tabil al þat he myȝte
Parfay quod he þe fanton is in myn hed
I ouȝt to deme of riȝtful iugement
That in þe salt se my wif is ded
And aftirward he made his argument
What wot I yf crist haue hir hidir sent
Mi wif be se as wel as he her sent
To my contre fro þens þat she went
And aftir anon hoom with þe senatour
Goth alla forto se þis wonder chaunse
This senatour doth Alla gret honour
And hasteli he sente aftir Custaunce
But trust wel her lust not to daunce
Whan she wiste wherfore was þᵗat sonde
Vnnethis vp on her feet myȝte she stonde
Whan Alla saw his wiff faire he her grette
And wepte þat it was routhe to se
For atte ferste loke þat he on her sette
He knew verili þat it was she
And for sorow as doumbe stondith as a tre
So was her herte shit in her distresse
Whan she remembrith of his vnkyndenesse
Twys she swownyth in his owen siȝte ¶
He wepte and him excusid pitousli
Now god qd he and his halowis briȝt
So wisli on my soule haue mercy
That of your harm as giltles am I
As is my sone Maurice so lik your face
Ellis þe fend me fecche out of þis place
Longe was the snobbynge ⁊and þe bitter peyn
Er þat her woful herte myȝte cece
Greet was þe pite forto here hem compleyn
Thorou whiche pleyntis gan her wo encrece
I pray you alle my labour to relece
I may telle her wo vntil to morow
I am so wery forto speke of sorow
But finalli whan þe soth is wist
That Alla giltlees is of hir wo
I trow an hundred tymes þey bekiste
And such a blisse is þere betwix ham two
That save þe ioie that lastith ever mo
Ther nys noon I lik þat ony creature
Hath seie or shal whilis þe worlde may dure
Tho preide she her husbonde mekely
In relesynge of her pitous peyne
That he wolde pray her fader spānlly
That l of his mageste he wolde enclyne
To vochesaaf sumtyme wᵗith him to dyne
She praieth him eek he sholde be no wey
Vnto hir fader no word sey of here sey
Sum men wolde seyn þat þe child Maurice
Doth þis message vnto the emperour
But as I gesse Alla was not so w nyce
To him þat is so souereyn of honour
As he that is of cristis folk þe flour
Sente eny childe but it is best to deme
He wente him self ⁊and so it may wel seme
This Emꝑperour hath guᵃntid gentilly ¶
To com to dyner as he him besouȝte
This Alla was redy he lokid bisily
Vpon þis childe and on his douȝter swetethoughteswete thoughte
Alla goth vnto his In and as him ouȝte
Araid for this feste in eueri wise
As ferforth as his kunnynge may suffize
The morow cam Alla gan him dresse
And eke his wif þis emꝑperour for to mete
And forth þey riden in ioie ⁊and in gladnesse
And whenne she saw her fader in þe strete
She liȝtith doun ⁊and fallith him to fete
Fader ꝙquod she your yonge child Custaunce
Is now ful cleen out of your remembraunce
I am your douȝter Custaunce ꝙquod she
That whilom ye haue sent in to Surre
It am I fader þat in the salt se
Was put alone ⁊and dampned forto dy
Now gode fader mercy I you crie
Send me nomore in to hethenesse
But thankith my lord here of his kyndenesse
Who can þe pitous ioie telle all
Betwix hem thre sithens þey be thus I met
But of my tale make an ende I shal
The day goth faste I may no lenger lette
Thise glad folk to dyner be I sette
In ioie and blisse at mete I lete ham duelle
A thowsand fold more þan y can telle
This child Maurice was sith Emꝑperour
I maad be the Pope ⁊and lyvid cristyn lyfcristyn lycristyn lyf
To cristis chirche dede he gret honour
But I lete al thise stories passe by
Of Custaunce is my tale spānlly
In olde Romaynes iestis men may wel fynde
Mauricius lif I bere it not in mynde
Thanne kyng Alla whan he his tyme say ¶
With Custaunce his holi wiff so swete
To engelond bith þey come þe riȝte way
Where as þey lyven in ioie ⁊and in quiete
But litil while it lasted I you behete
Ioye of þis worlde but a tyme it wol abide
Fro day to nyȝt it chaungith as þe tide
Who liveth ever in such delite aday
That ne meved is either in conscience
Or ire or talent or sum kynnys affray
Enuye or pride or passioun or offence
I ne sey but for þe ende of þis sentence
That litil while in ioie or plesaunce
Lastith þe blisse of Alla wᵗith Custaunce
For deth þat takith of hie ⁊and lowe his rente
Whenne passid was a yeer as I gesse
Out of this worle þis king Alla is went
For whom Custaunce hath ful gret hevynesse
Now pray we to god his soule blesse
And dame Custaunce finalli to say
Toward þe toun of Rome goth hir way
To Rome is come þis holi creature
And fyndeth her frendis þere hole ⁊and sound
Now is she scapid al her auenture
And when she hir fadir hath I founde
Doun on her knees fallith to grounde
Wepinge in herte for tendernesse blithe
She herieth god a hundred thousand sithe
In vertu ⁊and in holi almes dede
They liven alle ⁊and never asonder wende
Til deth departed ham þis lif þey lede
And farith now wel my tale is at an ende
Now Ihus crist þᵗat of his myȝt may sende
Ioie aftir woo gouerne vs in his grace
And kepe vs alle that been in þis place
Here endith the Man of lawis tale
Begynneth the squyeris prolog
OUr · ost in his stiroppis stondith anon
And saide gode men herkeneth euerichon̄
This was A thrifti tale for þe nonys
Sire Parissh preest quod he for goddis bonys
Tel vs A tale as was thi forward yore
I se wel þat lernyd men in lore
Conne moche good be goddis dignite
The Parson him answerde benedicite
What eilith þe man so sinfulli to swere
Oure ost Answerde Iankyn be ye there
I smelle A lollere in the wynd ꝙquod he
Now gode men quod our host herkeneth me
Abidith for goddis digne passioun̄
For we shul haue A predicacioıı̄un
This lollare wol prechen vs here sum what
Nay be my fader soule þᵗat shal he nat
Saide the squyer he shal not here preche
He shal no gospel glose here ne teche
Whe levith alle in þe grete god quod he
He wolde shewe sum difficulte
Or sprenche cokil in our clene corn̄
And therfore ost I warne the beforn̄
Mi ioli body shal atale telle
And I schal clynke ȝow so mery A belle
That it shal wakyn al this company
But it schal not be of philosophi
Ne phisilias ne termez queynte of lawe
There is but litil latyn in my mawe

At Surrey . at þe lond
of Tartarye

Here begynneth þe
Squyers tale
Ther duellid a kyng þat warrid on Russi
Thorow whiche þer dide many a douȝti man
This nobil kyng was clepid Cambuscan
Whiche in his tyme was of so greet Renoun̄
That þer was nowhere in no Regioıı̄un
So excellent A lord in alle thing
He lackid nouȝt þat longed to A kyng
As of the secte whiche he was born̄
He kepte his lay to whiche he was sworn̄
And þerto he was hardi wise ⁊and riche
Pitous . iust . and alwey Iliche
Soth of his worde . benigne ⁊and honurable
Of his corage as eny centir stabil
Yong fressh ⁊and strong ⁊and in Armys desirous

shyppys þe all
div.l: As ony bacheler of his hous
A fair ꝑpersone he was . and fortunate
And kepte Alwey . A rial astaat
That þer was nowhere such aman̄
This nobil king þis tartir Cambuscan
He hadde two sonys on Alphete his wiff
Of whiche þe eldest hiȝte Algarsif
That othir sone was clepid Camballo
A douȝter hadde þis worthi king Also
That yongest was ⁊and hiȝte Canace
But forto telle you of hir beaute
It lith not in my tunge ne in my konnynge
I dar not . take so high A thinge
Myn english eke is insufficient
I muste be A Rethour excellent
That cowde þe colours longing to þᵗat Art
If I sholde discrie hir eny part
I am no such I moste speke as I can̄
And so be fil this Cambuscan̄
Hath xxᵗⁱ wynter bore his diademe
As he wente fro yeer to yeer y deme
He leet the feste of his natiuite
Done crie thorow out Surr͗e þe cite
The laste Idus of Marche aftir þe yeer
Phebus þe sonne ful ioli was and cleer
For he was in his exaltacioıı̄un
In martis face and in his mansioıı̄un
In Aries the hote colerik signe
Ful lusty was þe wethir ⁊and benigne
For whiche þe foulis ayens þe sonne shene
That for þe seson and þe yonge grene
Wel loude song here Affecciouns
Hem semyd to getyn ayeen here protecciouns
Agayn þe swerd . of wynter kene ⁊and cold
In rial vestimentis sat on his days
With diademe ful hiȝ in his Paleys
And holdith his feste solempne ⁊and riche
That in this worlde was þer non it liche
Of which if I sholde telle al þe ray
Thanne wolde it occupie a someris day
And eke it nedith not to deuyse
At eueri cours þe ordre of her ʆseruize
I wol not telle of her stronge sewis
Ne of here swannys ne of her heronsewis
Eke in þᵗat lond as tellen knyȝtis olde
Is sum mete þat is ful deynte holde
That in þis lond men recke of it but smal
Ther is noman þat may reporten al
I wol not tarie you for it is pryme
And for it is no fruyt but los of tyme
Vnto my firste tale y wol haue my Recours
And so befil þᵗat aftir þe thridde cours
While þat þis kyng sat in his hiȝ nobleie
Herkenyng his mynstrallis here þingꝭis pleie
Beforn him at his bord deliciously
In atte halle dore sodeynly
Ther cam A knyȝt vpon A stede bras
And in his hond a brood merour of glas
And on his thombe he hadde of gold A ryng
And be his side A nakid swerd hanging
And vp he ridith to þe hiȝ borde
In al þe halle ne was þer spoke A word
For marvail of þis knyȝt him to be holde
And biseli þey waiten yonge ⁊and olde
The straunge knyȝt þat cam so sodenly
Al armed save his hed . ful richeli
He saluyd þe kyng ⁊and quene ⁊and lordꝭis alle
Bi ordre as þey sitten in þe halle
With so hiȝ reuerence ⁊and obeisaunce
As wel in speche as in his contenaunce
That Gawen with his olde curtesie
Thouȝ he com ayeen out of feirie
Ne coude him mende with a worde
Aftir þis before þe high bord
He with manli vois saide his message
Aftir þe fourme vsed in his langage
Withoute faille of sillabil or lettir
And for his tale sholde seme þe bettir
According to his word was his chere
As techith art of speche hi he ham þat it lere
Al be it þat y can not sowne his stil
Ne y can not clymbe on so hiȝ an hille
Thanne say I þus . to þe comyn entent
Thus muche Amountith þat he ment
If it so be I haue it in mynde
He saide þe king of Arabie ⁊and of ynde
div.note: ad propositūm
div.l: Mi liege lord on þis solempne day
Salueth yow as he best can and may
And sendith your honour at your feste
Be me that am Al redi at yoᵘur heste
This stede of bras þat eseli ⁊and wel
Can in the space of aday naturel
This is to say in xxiiij houris
Where you liste in drouȝte or in showris
Bere your body to eueri place
To whiche your herte willith forto pase
Withoute wem of you þorouȝ out foul or fair
Or yf you list to fle as hiȝ in þe heir
As doth an egil whanne him list to sore
This same stede shal bere you euermore
Withoute harm̄ til ye be there ye list
Thouȝ þᵗat ye slepe on his bac . or reste
And turne Ayeen with wryngyng of A pyn
He þat it wrouȝte knoweth many a gyn
He waitid many a constellacoıı̄un
Or he hadde þis operacioıı̄un
And knew meny a skil ⁊and meny a bonde
This myrour eke þat I haue in myn hond
Hath such a myȝt þat men may in it se
When þer shal falle eny aduersite
Vnto your regne or vnto your self also
And openli who is your frend or foo
And over al this if eny ladi briȝt
Hath set her herte in ony maner wiȝt
If he be fals she shal his treson se
His newe love and al his subtilite
So openli þat þer shal no þing hide
Wherfore agayns þis lusti someris tide
This myrour and þis ring as ye may se
He sente to my ladi Canace
Your excellent douȝter þat is here
The vertu of þis ring yf ye wol here
Is þis yf þat her list is forto were
Vpon here thombe or in her purs it bere
There is no foul þat fleeth vnder hevyn
That she ne shal vnderstonde his stevyn̄
And knowe his menyng openli ⁊and playn̄
And answere him in his langage Agayn̄
And eueri gras þat growith vpon þe rote
He shal knowe ⁊and whom it wol do bote
Al be his wounde never so deep or wide
This nakid swerd . þat hangith be my side
Such vertu hath . þat what man ye smyte
Thorow . out his Armure it wol kerve ⁊and bite
Were it as thicke as A braunchid ook
And what man it woundith wᵗith þe strook
He shal never be hool . til ye list of grace
To stroke him with þe plat in þe same place
There he is hurt þat is mykil to sayn̄
Ye moot with þe plat swerd agayn̄
Stroke hem in the wounde ⁊and it wol close
This is A verray soth withouten glose
It failith not whilis it is in yoᵘur holde
And whenne þe knyȝt hath þus his tale Itold
He rood out of þe halle and doun he liȝte
His stede which þat shoon as þe sonne briȝt
Stont in þe court stille as eny stoon̄
This knyȝt in to þe chambir is led Anon̄
And is vnarmed ⁊and to mete yset
The presentis be richeli kept
This is to say þe swerd ⁊and þe myrour
Been born anon in to þe tour
With certeyn officers ordeyned þerfore
And vnto Canace þis Ryng is bore
Solemly þere she sat at þe tabil
But sikirli withouten ony fabil
The hors of bras þat may not be remevid
It stont as it were in þe grounde Iclevid
For none engynys wyndas ne poleve
And cause whi for þey con not þe craft
And þerfore in þe place þey haue it laft
Til þat þe knyȝt haue tauȝt hem þe manere
To voiden him as ye shul aftir here
Greet was þe prees þat skermyd to ⁊and fro
To gaurin on þe hors þat stood so
For it so high was . so brood ⁊and so long
So well proporcioned to be strong
Riȝt as it were a stede of lumbardie
Therwith so horsli and so quyk of ye
As it a gentil poleyn courser were
For certis from his tail vnto his ere
Nature ne Art coude him not amende
In no degre as al þe pepil wende
But evermore her most wonder it was
How þᵗat it coude go and was of bras
It was of feire as al þe pepil semyd
Dyvers folk diuersli demede
As meny heddis . as meny wittꝭis þer been̄
They mormedyn as doth a swarm of been̄
And maken skilis aftir hir fantesie
Rehersynge of þe olde poetrie
And saide it was like þe pegase
The hors þat hadde wyngis forto fle
Or ellis it was the grekis hors Symoun̄
That brouȝte grekis vnto destruccioıı̄un
As men in thise olde gestis rede
Myn herte ꝙquod oon is evermore in drede
I trow sum men of Armys be þerynne
That shape hem þis cite forto wynne
It were riȝt good þᵗat al such thing were knowe
Another rowned to his felow . lowe
And saide he lied for it was rathir lik
An apparence maad be som magik
As iogelours pleyen at þe festis grete
Of sondri thouȝtis þus þey iangil ⁊and trete
As lewd pepil demed comonly
Of þingis þat been maad more subtilly
Thanne þey konne in here boundis comp̉rehende
They demyn gladli to þe badder ende
And some of theym wondrid on þe merour
That born was vp . in to þe maistir tour
Hou men myȝte in it suche þingis se
An other ansuerde and saide it may wel be
Naturelly be composicions
Of Aungelis and of sly refleccions
And saide þat in Rome was such on
They spak of Alceon and of Vitelon̄
And of Aristotill that writin in her lyvis
Of queynte myrours And of prospecfatiuis
As knowe they þat haue her bokis herd
And othir folk haue wondrid on þe swerd
That wol ꝑperissh þorouȝ everi þing
And fil in speche of Thelephus þe kyng
And of Achilles for his queynte spere
For he coude with it boþe hele ⁊and dere
Riȝt in such wize . as men may wᵗith þe swerd
Of whiche riȝt now ye haue your self yherd
They speken of sondry hardyng of metal
And speken of medicines þerwith Al
And how . and whanne it sholde hardit be
Which vnknowe is algate to me
To speke þanne of Canaces ryng
And said þat al such wonder þing
Of craft of ringis herde þey nevir non̄
Save that be moises and be kyng Salamon̄
Hadde A maner connynge of such an art
Thus seyn þe pepil ⁊and drawen ham Apart
But nevertheles some saide þat it was
Wonder to make of fern̄ glas
And ȝit is glas not lik asshen of fern̄
But for þey haue knowe it so fern̄
Therfore cecith her iangelynge ⁊and her wonder
As sore wondre som be cause of þe thundir
On ebbe . on flood . on gossomer ⁊and on myste
And on Al þing til þe cause is wist
Thus iangelyn they ⁊and demyn · ⁊and deuyse
Til þat þe kyng gan from his bord arise
Phebus hath lost þe angil meredional
And ȝit ascending was þe best rial
The gentil lioun̄ with his Aldriane
Whanne þat þis tartir king Cambuscan
Roos from his bord þere he sat ful hie
Beforn him goth þe lowde minstralcie
Til þat he cam to his chambir of parementꝭis
There as þey sownyn dyuers in instrumentꝭis
That is lik An heven to here
Now daunsen lusty venus children dere
For in þe fish her lady sat ful hie
And lokith on hem with A frendly ye
This nobil king is set vp on his trone
This straunge knygh is fet to him ful sone
And on þe daunce he goth with Canace
There is þe Revel and þe Iolite
That is nat abil adul man to devise
He muste haue knowe love ⁊and his ʆseruize
And be as festliche man as fresh may
That shul you deuysen such aray
Who coude you telle þe fourme of daunsis
So vncouthe ⁊and so fressh contenaunces
And þerto such subtil lokyngis
For drede of Ielosie of mennys presingis
No man but launcelot ⁊and he is ded
Þerfore I passe ovir of Al þis lustihede
I say nomore but in this iolynesse
I lete hem til men to soꝑper hem dresse
The Stiward biddith spicis forto hie
And eke the wyne in al this melodie
The vsshers ⁊and þe squiers ben gon̄
The spicis ⁊and þe wyne is comen Anon̄
They ete ⁊and drynke ⁊and whan þis was at ende
Vnto þe tempil as reson was þey wende
The seruize doth þey þat day
What nedith you to reherce here Aray
Eche man woot wel þat A kyngis feste
Hath plente to þe moste ⁊and to þe leste
And deyntees mo þan be in my knowyng
And aftir soper goth þis nobil kyng
To se þis hors of bras with al þe route
Of lordis ⁊and of ladies him aboute
Such wondryng was þerof þis hors of bras
That sethen þe grete sege of troie was
There as men on an hors also
Ne was þer such awondryng as was tho
But finalli þe king asked þe knyȝt
The vertu of þis courser ⁊and þe myȝt
And praide to telle him his goủernaunce
The hors anon gan to trippe ⁊and daunce
Whan þat þis knyȝt leide hond on his reyne
And saide sere þer is nomore to sayne
But if ȝow list to riden eny where
Ye moste trille a pyn þat stont in his ere
Which I shal you betwixt vs two
Ye moot nempne him to what place also
Orto what cuntre ye list to ride
And whanne ye come þere . ye list abide
Bid him descende ⁊and trille anoþer pyn
For þere ynne lith þe effect of al þe gyn̄
And he wol doun descende ⁊and do al your wil
And in that place he wol abide stil
Theyȝ al þe worlde hadde þe contrari swore
He shal not thens be drawe ne bore
And Or And Or if you list bidde him þens goon̄
Trille this pynne ⁊and he wol vanysshe Anon̄
Out of þe siȝte of eueri maner wiȝt
And come ayen be it day or nyȝt
What þat yow list clepyen him Ayeen̄
In such a gise as I shal to you seyn̄
Betwene me ⁊and you ⁊and þat riȝt sone
Ride whenne you list þer is nomore to done
Enfourmed whan þe king was of þe knyȝt
And hath conceyued in his wit ariȝt
The maner and þe fourme of al þis thing
Ful glad ⁊and blithe was this nobil kyng
Repeiryng vnto his Revel as beforn̄
The bridil is in to þe tour yborn̄
And kept among his iewels leef ⁊and dere
The hors vanysshed I not in what manere
Out of her siȝte ye get nomore of me
But thus ylete in lust ⁊and in iolite
This Cambuscan his lordis festing
Til wel nyȝ þe day be gan to sprynge
The norice of digestiouns þe sleep
Gan on ham wynke ⁊and bad ham take kepe
That muche mete and labour wol haue reste
And with a galpyng mouth he ham alle keste
And saide it was tyme to lie adoun̄
For blood was in his dominacioıı̄un
Cherissheth blood natures frend ꝙquod he
They thankyn him galpinge be two be thre
And eueri wiȝt gan drawe him to his rest
As sleep ham bad ⁊and took it for þe best
Here dremys shul not be told for me
Ful were here heddis of fumosite
That causith dreme of which þer is no charge
They slepyn til it was pryme large
The moste part but it were Canace
She was ful mesurable as wommen be
For of her fader hadde she take her leve
To go to reste sone aftir it was Eve
Here list not apalled forto be
Ne on þe morow vnfestliche forto be be se
And slept her firste sleep̄ and awook
For such ioie she in hir myrouʳ took
Bothe of here queynt ring ring ⁊and hir myrour
That xxᵗⁱ tyme she chaungith hir colour
And in her sleep̄ for here impression̄
Of hir merour she hadde a vision̄
Wherfore or þe sonne gan vp glide
She clepid vp her maistresse here beside
And saide þat her lust forto arise
Thise olde wommen þat ben gladli wise
As her maistres . answerde here Anon
And saide Madame whethir wol ye goon̄
Thus erli for folk been alle in reste
I wol quod she arise for me liste
No lengir slepe but walken aboute
Her maistresse clepith wommen a greet Route
And vp þey risen wel ten . or twelve
Vp risith fresh Canace her selve
As redy and briȝt as þe yong sonne
That in the Ram is . ten degrees yronne
No hiȝer was she whanne she redy was
And forth she walkith eseli a paas
Araid aftir þe lusti seson sote
Liȝtly for to pley and walkyn on fote
Not . but v or vj of her meyne
And in A trench ferre in a park goth she
The vapour whiche fro þe erthe glode
Makith þe sonne to seme rody ⁊and brood
But neverthelesse it was fair of siȝte
That it made alle her hertes for to liȝte
What for þe seson and þe Mornynge
And for þe foulis þat she herde synge
For riȝt anon she wiste what þey ment
Riȝt be here song ⁊and knew al here entent
The knotte whi that euery tale is told
If it be taried til lust be colde
Of ham þᵗat haue it harkened aftir yere
The sauour passith and ever lenger þe more
For fulsamnesse of prolixite
And bi the same reson thinkith me
I sholde vnto the knotte condescende
And make of hir walkyng an ende
A mydde a tre for drede as white as chalk
As Canace was pleyynge in her walk
Thersat a fawcon over her hed ful hie
That with a pitous vois so gan to crie
That al þe wode resouned of her crie
And beten hadde her self so pitouslie
With bothe her wyngis til þe rede blood
Ran endlong þe tre as she stood
And evir in one she cride alwey ⁊and shrite
And with her bek her self she pite
That þer nas tigre nor cruel beste
That duellith other in wode or in forest
That wolde haue wept if he wepe coude
For sorow of her she shrit alwey so lowde
For þer was neuer ȝit man on lyve
Yf þat I coude a faucon wel descryve
Or herde of such annothir of feirnes
As wel of plumage as of gentilnes
Of shapthe of al þat myȝte Irekened be
A facon ꝑperegryn thanne semed she
Of frend lond · and evirmore as she stood
She swowned now and now for lak of blood
Til wel nyȝ is she fallen fro þe tre
This faire kyngis douȝter Canace
That on her fynger baar þe queynte ring
Thorow . whiche she vnderstood wel every þing
That eny foul may in his leden sayn
And coude Answere in his leden agayn
She hath vnderstonde what þis faucon saide
And wel nygh for routhe she deide
And to the tre she goth ful hastely
And on this facon lokith ful pitously
And held her lappe abrood for wel she wiste
The facon muste falle fro the twiste
Whan þat it swowned next for lak of blood
A longe while to waite where she stood
Til at þe laste she spak in þis manere
Vnto þe hauk as ye shul aftir here
What is þe cause if it be forto telle
That ye be in this furial peyne of helle
Quod Canace vnto this hauk above
Is þer sorow of deth or ellis of love
For as I trow thise been þe causis two
That causith most a gentil herte wo
Of other harm it reckith not to speke
For your self vp on your self wolde wreke
Whiche þat preveth wel þᵗat oþer Ire or drede
Mot be encheson of your cruel dede
Syn þat I se non oþer wiȝt you chace
For loue of god so do your self grace
Or what may be your help for west ne est
Saw I nevir or now brid nor best
That ferde with him self so pitousli
Ye sle me with your sorou verily
I haue of you so gret compassioıı̄un
For goddis love com fro þe tre adoun
And as I am A kyngez douȝter trewe
If þat I verili þe causis knewe
Of your diseze if þat it lay in my myȝt
I wolde amende it or it were nyȝt
As wis helpe me grete god of kynde
And herbis shal I riȝt ynowe fynde
To hele with your hurtis hastely
Tho shrite this facoun more pitousli
Thanne ever she did ⁊and fil to grounde Anon̄
And lith aswowne . as ded as ony stoon̄
Til Canace hath in her lappe ytake
Vnto that tyme she gan out of her swowne awake
And aftir þat she out of swoun · gan braide
Riȝt in her hawkis lide thus she saide

div.l: That pite rennyth sone in gentil herte
Felyng is similitude in peynes smerte
Is provid al day as men may se
As wel bi work As bi auctorite
For gentil herte kidith gentilnesse
I se wel þat ye haue of my distresse
Compassioun my faire Canace
Of verri wommanli benignite
That nature in your principlis hath set
But for no hope forto fare þe bet
But forto obeie to your herte fre
And forto make other be waar be me
As bi the whelp chastized is þe lioun
Riȝt for þat cause and that conclusion
While þat I haue leiser ⁊and spaas
Myn harm y wil confesse er I paas
And ever while þat on · her sorow tolde
That othir wepte as she to water wolde
Til þat þe faucon bad hir be stille
And with a sigh thus she said her wille
There y was bred . allas þat day
And fostrid . in A roche of marbil grey
So tenderli þat no þing ailid me
I ne wiste what was aduersite
Til I coude fle . ful hie vnder þe sky
Tho dwellid a tarcelet me faste by
That semed velle of al gentilnes
Al were he ful of treson and falsnes
That is wrappid vnder humble chere
And vnder hue of trouthe in such manere
Vnder plesaunce ⁊and vnder besi peyne
That no wiȝt wolde haue wend he coude feyne
So depe in greyn he died in colours
Riȝt as a serpent hidith him vnder flouris
Til he may se his tyme forto bite
Riȝt so this god of love þis þis is Ipocrite
Doth so his sermons ⁊and his obeisauncis
And kepith in semblaunce al his obʆseruauncis
That souneth vnto gentilnesse of love
As in a tombe is al þe feir above
And vnder is þe cors such as ye woot
Such was this Ipocrit bothe cold ⁊and hoot
And in this wise he servid his entent
That save the fende noman wist what he ment
Til he so longe hadde wept ⁊and compleyned
And meny a yeer his seruize vnto me feyned
Til that my herte to pitous and to nyce
Al Innocent of his crounyd malice
For ferd of his deth as thouȝte me
Vp on his othis and his suerte
Graunte him loue vp on this condicioıı̄un
That euermo myn honour ⁊and my renoun̄
Were saued bothe pryue and apert
This is to seyn that aftir his desert
I yaf him al my herte ⁊and my þouȝt
God woot ⁊and he and other wize nouȝt
And toke his herte in chonge of myn for ay
But soth is said . goon seth is many aday
A trewe wiȝt and a theef thinke not on̄
And whan he saw the thing so fer agon̄
That I grauntid him my love
In such agise as y haue said above
And yeue him my trewe herte as fre
As he swoor he yaf his herte to me
Anon this tigre ful of doubilnesse
Fil on his knees with so gret humblenesse
With hiȝ reuerence ⁊and as bi his chere
So lik a gentil louer in manere
So rauysshed as it semed for ioie
That neuer Iason ne Paris of troie
Iason certis ne non other man
Syn lameth was þat alderfirst began
To loven too too as writen folk beforn̄
Ne nevir sith þat first man was born̄

div.l: To ony womman were she nevir so wise
So payntid he his chere at poynt device
As wel his wordis as his contenaunce
And so I loued him for his obeisaunce
And for the trowthe I demed in his hert
That if so were þat eny thing him smert
Al were it neuer so lite ⁊and I it wiste
Me thouȝte I herde deth at my herte twiste
And shortli so ferforth þis þing is went
That my wil was his willis instrument
This is to sey my wil obeied to his wil
In alle þing aftir þat reson fil
Keping þe boundis of my worship ever
Ne never hadde y thing so leef ne lever
As him god woot ne neuer shal nomo
This lastid lenger thanne a yeer or two
That I supposid of him no thing but good
But finalli thus at þe laste it stood
That fortune wolde þat he must twynne
Out of þat place which I was ynne
Where me was it is no questioun̄
I can not make of it discripcioıı̄un
For o thing dar y telle boldly
I knowe what þe peyne of deth is therby
Such harm I mette þᵗat he ne myȝte me leve
So on aday of me he took his leve
So sorowfulli eke that y wende verily
That he hadde felt as moche sorou as y
When þat I herde him speke ⁊and saw his hewe
But neverthelesse I thouȝte he was so trewe
And eke that he repaire sholde ageyn̄
With ynne A litil while soth to sayn̄
And reson wolde eke that he moste go
For his honour ⁊and ofte it fallith so
That I made vertu of necessite
And took it wel syn it moste be
As I best myȝte I hidde fro him my sorow
And took him be þe hond seint Iohn̄ to borow
And I saide thus . lo I am youris al
Bothe such as I haue be to you ⁊and shal
What he Ansuerde nedith not to reherce
Who can say bet þan he who can do wers
Whanne he hath al said than hath he doon̄
Therfore behoueth him a long spoon̄
That shal ete with a fend thus herde I say
So atte laste he muste forth his way
And forth fleith til he com þere him list
When it cam him to pᵘurpos forto reste
I trow he hadde þe text in mynde
That al þing repeirith to his kynde
Gladith him self thus sey men as I gesse
Men love of propir kynde newe fangilnesse
As briddis doon̄ þat men in cagis fede
For þey thowe nyȝt ⁊and day take of hem hede
And strawe her cage feire ⁊and softe as silk
And yeue hem suger hony bred ⁊and mylk
Ȝit riȝt anon as his dore is shit vp
He with his feet wol spurne doun his cup̄
And to þe wode he wol and wormes ete
So newfangil bith þey of her mete
And loue nouelles of proꝑper kynde
No gentilnesse of blood may him bynde
So ferde this Tarcellet allas the day
Thouȝ he were gentil born̄ fresh and gay
And good forto se humble and fre
He saw vp on atyme a kite fle
And sodenli he louyd this kite so

div.l: That al his loue is clene fro me go
And hath his trouthe falsid in this wise
Thus hath þe kite my loue in his ʆseruize
And I am lorn withoute remedy
And with þat word þis facon gan to cry
And swouned eft in Canaces arm
Greet was the sorou for the hawkꝭes harm
That Canace ⁊and alle her wommen made
They nyste how þey myȝte the facon glade
But Canace hom berith her͗ in her lappe
And softly in plasteris gan her wrappe
There as she with her beek hadde hurt her self
Now can not Canace but herbis delf
Out of þe ground ⁊and make saucis newe
Of herbis precious ⁊and fyne of hewe
To hele with þe hauk fro day to nyȝt
She doth her besines and al here myȝt
And bi her beddis hed she made a mewe
And couered it with veluettis newe
In signe of trouthe þᵗat is in wommen seen
And al withoute þe mewe ypentid green̄
In whiche were peyntid al þise false foulis
As been thise tidiffis . tarcellis ̄m owlis
Riȝt for despit were peyntid her beside
Pies on theym forto crie and chide
Thus lete I Canace her hauk keping
I wol as now nomore speke of her Ryng
Til it come efte to purpoos forto sayn
How þat this faucon gat her love Agayn
Repentaunce as the stori tellith vs
Be mediacion of Cambalus
The kingis sone of whiche I ȝou tolde
But hens forth I wol processe holde
To speken of auenturis ⁊and of bataillis
That yit was neuer herd so grete m̉ervaillis
First y wol you telle of Cambuscan
That in his tyme many a cite wan
And aftir wol y speke of Algarsif
How that he wan theodora to his wif
For whom ful ofte in greet peril he was
Ne hadde he be holpin be the hors of bras
And aftir wol I speke of Cambalo
That fauȝt in listis with bretheren two
For Canace or that he myȝte here wynne
And there I lefte I wol ayen · begynne

That weddid be I trow þat it be so
For wel I woot it fareth so be me
I haue awiff þe worste that may be
For thouȝ þe feend couplid to here were
She wolde him ouermacche y dar wel swere
What sholde I you reherce in special
Her high malice she is a shrewe at Al
Ther is along and alarge difference
Betwix grisildis . grete pacience
And of my wiff þe passing cruelte
Were I vnbounde also mot I the

Asay who so wol and he shal finde
That y say soth be saynt Thomas of Inde

A good sir ost I haue weddid be

¶chuntis tale
Som tyme þ̉erwas duellynge in lumbardie
A worthi knyȝt þᵗat born was at pavy
In whiche he lyvid in gret prosꝑperite
And lx . yeer awyflees man was he
And folowid his bodili delit
On wommen was his hool appetit
As doon thiȝe folis þat ben seculer
And whanne þat he was passid lx . ȝeer
Were it for holinesse or for dotage
I can not say but such a gret corage
Hadde this knȝt to be a weddidman
That day and nyȝt he doth al þat he can
To aspie where he myȝte weddid be
Prayyng our lord grauntinge þᵗat he
Miȝte onys knowe that blisful lif
That is betwix an husbonde ⁊and his wif
And forto lyue vnder þe holi hond
With þe whiche god first man ⁊and wōmman bond
Non oþer lif saide he is worth abene
For wedlok is so esi and so clene
That in this worlde it is a paradise
Thus saide this olde knyȝt þat was so wise
And certeynli as soth as god is kyng
To take a wif it is a glorious thing
And nameli whan aman is old ⁊and hoor
Thenne is a wif þe fruyt of his tresoor
Thanne sholde he take a yong wif ⁊and a fair
On whiche he myȝte engendre him an heir
And lede his lif in ioie and in solace
Where as thise bachelers syngen allas
When þat þey finde eny aduersite
In loue which þᵗat is but childis vanite
And treveli it sit wel to be so
That bachelers haue ofte peyne ⁊and woo
On brotil ground þey bilde brotilnesse
They finde freelte whan þey wene sikirnesse
They lyve but as a brid or as a best
In liberte and vnder non areest
There as a weddid man is in astaat
Lyveth his lif blisful in ordinate
Vnder þe yok of mariage I bounde
Wel may his herte in ioie ⁊and blisse habounde
For who can be so buxum as a wif
Who is so trewe who is so tentif
To kepe him seek ⁊and hool ⁊and is his make
For weel or woo she wol nat him forsake
She is nat wery him to love ⁊and serve
Thouȝ he ly bedrede til he sterve
And ȝit some clerkis sayn it is not so
Of whiche Theophraste is on of tho
What fors theiȝ Theophraste doth he
Ne take no wif quod he for husbondrie
As forto spare in housholde thin expence
A trewe seruaunt doth more diligence
Thi good to kepe þan dost thi self wif
For she wol clayme half part al her lif
And if that thow be seek so god me save

tale
LOrdyngis qd . he in chirchis when I preche
I peyne me to haue an haunten speche ¶
I ryyng it as round as goth a belle
For I can be roote al that I telle
My teme is evir one and alwey was
Radix malorum est cupiditas
First I pronounce whens þᵗat I cam
And þanne my billis shewe I alle ⁊and som
Our liege lordis seel is my patent
That shewe I first . my body to warent
That no man be so bolde ne preest ne clerk
Me to distourbe of cristis holi werk
And aftir þat telle I forth my talis
Bullis of Popis and of Cardinalis
Of Patriarkis and bisshoppis I shewe
And in latyn I speke wordis a fewe
To saveryn with my predicacioun
And forto stere . men . to deuocioun
Thenne shewe I forth my longe cristal stones
I crāmmyd in cloutis ful of bonys
Relikes . they been as wenyn þey echon
Thanne haue I in latou a sholdirbon
Which þat was an holi Iewis sheep
Gode men say I take of my wordis keep
If that this boon be wasshe in eny welle
Yf kow . or calf sheep . or . oxe swelle
That ony worm hath ete or him stonge
Touche he this boon . anone he shal be founde
And ȝit also of ferthirmore
Of pokkis and of scabbis and eueri sore
Shal euery sheep be hool þᵗat of þis welle
Or drynketh a drauȝte take kepe of þᵗat what I telle
Wol euery wiȝt . or þat þe cook him kervith
And . do þing that him oweth
Fastynge drynke of þis welle a drauȝte
As þat holi Iew our eldris tauȝte ¶
His bestis and his stoor shal multiplie
And siris also it helith ielousie
And þouȝ aman befalle in gelous rage
Leet make with this watir his potage
And nevir shal he more his wiff mystruste
Thowȝ he defaute bi her wiste
Al had she take prestis . two . or thre
Here is a meteyn . eek ye may se
He that his hond . wol put in þat meteyn
He shal haue multiplyyng of his greyn
Whanne he hath sowen be it whete or otys
So þat he offre penys or ellis grotis
And men . and wommen o thing warne I yow
If ony wiȝt be in this chirche now
That hath doon synne horrible þat he
Dar not for shame shryvyn be
Or eny womman be she yong or olde
That hath ymaad her husbond Cokewolde
Such folk shal haue no power ne grace
To offir to my relikes in this place
And who so fyndith him out of such blame
Comyth vp and offir in goddis name
And I assoille hem be þe auctorite
Such as be bull was grauntid me
Be þis gaude haue y wonne many a yeer
An hundrid mark syn I was pardoner
I stonde lik a clerk in many A Pulpet
And shewe . lewd pepil ⁊and doun þey set
I preche so as ye haue herd be fore
And telle an hundrid Iapis more
Than peyne y me to strecche forth myn necke
And est and west vpon þe pepil I becke
As doth a dowue sittynge vpon a bern
Myn hondis ⁊and my tonge gon so yern ¶
That it is ioie to se my besines
Of auarice and such cursidnes
Is al my prechinge to make hem fre
To yeue her penys and nameli vnto me
For myn entent is not but forto wynne
And no thing for correccion of synne
I recke not whenne þᵗat þey be beried
Thouȝ her soulis goon a blakeberied
For certis many a predicacioun
Sowneth ofte tyme of evil entencioun
Some for plesaunce of folk and for flaterye
To ben auauncid be ypocrisie
And som for veynglory . and som for hate
For whenne y dar not othir while debate
Than wol I stynge hem wᵗith my tonge smerte
In prechinge so þᵗat þey shul not asterte
To ben diffamed falsli yf þat he
Hath trespassid othir to my bretheryn or to me
For þouȝ I telle not his proꝑper name
Men shal wel knowe it is þe same
Be Symonie or be othir circumstauncis
Thus quyte I folk þᵗat doth vs displesaunce
Thus spit I out my venym vnder hewe
Of holynes . to seme holi and trewe
But shortli myn entent I wol devise
I preche of no thing but of couetise
Of this mater it ouȝt I now suffiȝe
Thanne telle I of ensamplis many on
Of olde stories longe tyme agoon
For lewd pepil lovyn talis olde
Which þyngis can þey weel reporte ⁊and holde
What trow ye whilis þᵗat I may preche
And forto wynne gold ⁊and siluer forto teche
That I wil lyve in pouert wilfully ¶
Nay nay I thouȝte it nevir trewly
For I wol preche ⁊and begge in sondri londis
I wil not do no labour with my hondis
And make baskettis and lyve þerby
Be cause I wol not begge Idelly
I wil non of the Apostelis countirfete
I wol haue money . chese and whete
Al were it euer of þe porest page
Or of the porest widow in a village
Al sholde her childryn sterve for famyn
Nay I wol drynke þe licour of þe wyn
And haue a ioly wenche in euery . toun
But herkeneth lordingis in conclusiou
Your likyng is þᵗat I shal telle a tale
Now y haue dronke a drauȝte of corny Ale
By god y hope I shal telle you a thing
That shal be reson and at your likynge
For thouȝ my self be a ful vicious man
Amore ille tale ȝit I yow telle can
Which I am wont forto preche ⁊and forto wyn
Now holde your pees my tale I wol begynne
IN flaundris sumtyme was a company
Of yonge folk þat hauntedyn foly
As riot hazard . Stewis and tauernys
They daunce and pleye atte dyce both day ⁊and nyȝt
And etyn and drynkyn also ouer her myȝt
Thorow whiche þey doon þe devil sacrifize
With ynne þe devill tempil in cursid wise
The suꝑparfluytees abhominabil
Here othis . be so grete ⁊and Dampnabil
That it is grisly forto here hem swere
Our blissid lordis body þey to tere .
Hem þouȝte Iewis rente him not I nowȝ
And ech of hem at othir synnys lowȝ ¶
And riȝt anone cam the Tomblesteris
Fetis and smale and yong fruterestris
Syngars with harpis Bawdis wafreris
Such as been verry þe deuyll officeris
To kyndil . and blowe the firis of lecherie
That is annexid to glotonie
The holi writ take I to witnesse
That lecherie is in wyne ⁊and in dronkenesse
Lo how þᵗat dronkyn loth vnkyndely
Lay be his douȝtris two vnwetyngly
So dronke he was he nyste what he wrouȝte
And þerfore sore repentid him ofte
Herodis who so wol þe stories seche
There may ye lerne ⁊and be ensampil teche
Whan he of wyne was repleet at his feste
Riȝt at his owen tabil yaf his heste
To sle the Baptist Iohn ful giltlees
Senek saith eke gode wordis doutles
He saith he can no difference fynde
Betwix aman þᵗat is oute of his mynde
And aman þᵗat is dronkelew
But that woodnes fallyn is in a shrew
Perseuerith lenger than doth dronkenes
O glotenye ful of cursidnes
O cause first of our confusioun
O . original of our dampnaciou
Til crist hadde bouȝt vs wᵗith his blood ageyn
Lo how dere and shortly was to seyn
Abouȝt was this cursid vilony
Corupt was al this world þorou glotony
Adam our fader and his wif also
Fro paradise to labour and to woo
Were dryven for that vice it is no drede
For whilis þᵗat Adam fastid as I rede ¶
He was in Paradise ⁊and whanne þat he
Ete of the fruyt defendid . on a tre
Anon . he was out cast to woo ⁊and peyne
O glotenye . on þe ouȝte vs wel to pleyne
O wiste amān how meny maladies
Folowith of excesse and of glotenyes
He shal be þe more mesurabil
Of his diete sittyng at his tabil
Allas þe short throte . þe tendir mouth
Makith þat . est ⁊and west North . ⁊and south
In erthe . in eyr in watir men to swynke
To gete a gloton mete ⁊and drynke
O poul of this mater wel canst thow entrete
Mete vnto wombe and wombe vnto mete
Shal god destroien bothe as Poule saith
Allas a foul þing it is be my feith
To say this worde and foulir is þe dede
Whenne men so drynkith of þe white ⁊and rede
That of his throte he makith his pryve
Thorow þat cursid superfluyte
The Apostil wepinge saith ful petosly
Ther wakkyn meny of whiche you told haue I
I say it now wepynge with pitous vois
Ther been . enemyys of cristis crois
Of whiche þe ende is deth þe wombe is her god
O wombe . o . holy . o . stynkynge cod
Fulfillid of dung and of corupciou
And either ende of þe foul is þe soun
How gret cost and labour is to fynde
Thise cokis how þey stompe . streyne ⁊and grynde
And turne substaunce in to accident
To fulfille al thi c licorous talent
Out of þe harde bonys knockyn þey
The mary for þey caste nauȝt awey ¶
That may go thorow þe s golet softe ⁊and sote
Of spicery of levis barke . and rote
Shal be his cause ymade delite
To make him anewer appetite
But certis he that hauntith such delitis
Is ded whilis þat he livith in þe vicis
A lecherous þing is wyne and dronkenesse
Is ful of stryvynge and of wrecchidnesse
O dronken man disfugurid in thi face
Foul is thi breth foul art thou to embrace
And þorow thin dronkyn nose sownyth thi soun
As thouȝ saidist ay Sampsoun . Sampsoun
And ȝit god woot Sampson . drank nevir no wyn
Thou farist as it were a . stikid swyn
Thi tonge is lost . and al thyn honest curis
For dronkenes is verri sepulturis
Of mannys wit and his discreciou
In whom þat drynke hath dominaciou
He can no counsel kepe it is no drede
Now kepe you fro þe white ⁊and fro þe rede
Nameli fro þe white wyne of lepe
That is to selle in fissh strete or in chepe
This wyne of Spayne crepith sotilly
In othir wynys growyng fast by
Of which þer risith such fumosite
That whenne aman hath dronkyn drauȝtꝭes thre
And wenyth that he be atte toune in chepe
He is in Spayne riȝt at þe town of lepe
Not at Rochel ne at bordeux town
And wol þey say . Sampsoun . Sampsoun
But herkenyth lordingꝭes . o . word I you pray
That al þe souereyn actis dar I say
Of victories in þe olde testament
That þorou very god þᵗat is omnipotent ¶
Were doon in abstinence and in praier
Lokith þe Bibil and þere ye mowe it lere
Lokith Atilla þe grete conquerour
Dide in his sleep . with shame . ⁊and dishonour
Bledynge ay at his nose in dronkenes
A Capteyn sholde lyve in sobirnes
And . ouyr al this . avise yow riȝt weel
What was comaundid vnto lamuel
Nat . Samuel . but . lamuel . say I
Redith þe Bibil and fynd it expresly
Of wyne yevynge to hem þᵗat haue Iustice
Nomore of this for it may wel suffiȝe
And now that I haue spoke of gloteny
Now wol I defende you hasardry
Hasardrie is very moder of lesyngis
And of disceit . cursid forsweryngis also
Of bataille . ofte tyme and of oþir mo
It is repreef and contrari of to honour
Forto beholden a Comune hasardour
And evir þe hier that he is in astat
The more he is holden dissolate
If þat aprince vse hazardrie
In al gouernaunce ⁊and al polecye
He is . as bi comune oppiniou
I holde the lasse . in reputaciou
Stillebone þat was holde . A . wise Embassetoᵘur
Was sent into Carneth wᵗith gret honour
Fro Calidone . to make hem aliaunce
And whanne he cam him happith þis chaunce
That alle the grettist þat were of his lande
Pleyynge atte hazarde he hem fonde
For whiche as sone as þat it myȝte be
He stale him hoom ayeen to his contre
And saide þere wil I not lese my name ¶
I wol not take on me so gret defame
You forto alye to non . hasardouris
Sendith oþer wise Ambassiatouris
For be my trouthe me were lever die
Thanne I you to hasardouris shulde alie
For ye that been so glorious in honouris
Shal not allie you to hasardouris
As be my wil as ne as be my trete
This wise Philisophir þus said to me
Loke þou vse no pley of dise in thi hous
Loke eke how to þe king Emetrus
Sente him a peire of dise in scorn
For he hadde vsed hasardrie þerbeforn
For which he held his glorie and his renoun
At no value of Reputacioun
Lordis myȝten fynde othir maner pley
Honest ynouȝ to dryue þe day awey
NOw . wol I speke of othis fals . ⁊and grete
A word . or two as many bokes entrete
Greet sweryng is thing abhominabil
And fals sweryng is a thing more reprofhabil
The high god forbad sweryng at all
Witnesse . of Mathew . but in special
Of swering saith holi Ierome
Thow shalt swere soth thyn othis ⁊and not lye
And swere in dome and in riȝtwisnes
But ydil sweryng is A cursidnes
Behold and se þat in þe firste tabil
Of hiȝ goddis hestis honurabil
How þat þe seconde heste of him is this
Take not myn name in idilnes amys
Lo rather he forbedith such sweryng
Or homycidy . or ony oþer cursid þing
I say . as be ordre þus it stondith ¶
This knoweth þey þat his hestis vnderstondith
Hou þat þe secunde heste of god is þat
And furthir more I wil þe telle al plat
That vengeaunce shal not parte from þe hous
That of his othis outrageous
Ey . be goddis precius herte ⁊and be his nailis
And be his blood . þat is in heilis
Sevyn is my . chaunce ⁊and thin is fyve ⁊and thre
Ey goddis armys yf thou falsly pley wᵗith me
This daggar shal þorow thyn herte go
This fruyt comyth of þe bicchid bonys two
Forsweringe . Ire . falsnes ⁊and homicide
Now for þe loue of crist þat for vs dide
Levith your othis bothe grete ⁊and smale
For cristis sake . and harkenyth my tale
¶ Thise riotouris . thre of which I telle
Longe or pryme ronge ony belle
Were set hem in a tauerne to drynke
And as þey sat they herde a belle clynke
Before a cors was caried to his grave
That on of hem gan calle to his knave
Go bet quod he . and axe redily
What cors is this þat passith forth by
And loke þᵗat thow reporte his name wel
Sere quod þe boy it nedith nevir adeel
It was me told . or ye cam here two houris
He was parde an old felow of youris
Al sodenli was he sleyn to nyȝt
For dronke as he sat on his bench vpriȝt
Ther cam apryve theef men clepe deth
That in his contre al pepil sleth
And with his sper he smot his herte in two
And wente his wey with oute wordis mo
And maistir er ye come in his presence . ¶
He hath a thousand sleyn þis pestelence
Me thinkith it were necessary
Forto bewaar of such an aduersari
Deth is redy forto mete him euermore
Thus tauȝte me my dame I say nomore
O saynte Mari said þis tauernere
The child saith soth for he hath to ȝere
Hens ouyr amyle in a gret village
Bothe man and womman child ⁊and page
I trow his habitacion be there
To been avisid gret wisdom it were
Er that he did aman A . dishonour
Ye goddis armys saide this riotour
Is it such peril with him forto mete
I shal him seke bedale and eke be strete
I shal him se be goddis digne bonys
Harkyn felowis we thre been alonys
Let ech of vs becomyn othirs brother
And ech of vs holde vp . his hond to other
And we wol sle this fals traitour deth
He shal . be slayn he þᵗat somany sleth
Be goddis dignite or it be nyȝt
To gedir haue thise thre her hertis hiȝt
To lyve and dye ilke of theym wᵗith othir
Thouȝ he were his owen swore brothir
And vp þey stert al dronke in this Rage
And forth þey goon toward þat village
Of which þe tauerner hath spoke beforn

The pepil roos vpon him . on an nyȝt
For his . defaute and whanne he it aspide
Out of his doris anon he hath him diȝt
Alone and þere he . wende haue be alysid
He knockid fast . and ay þe more he cride
The fastir shit þey the dorys . alle
Tho wiste he wel he had him self begilid
And wente His way no lengir durste He calle
The pepil cride . and romblid vp . and doun
That with his eris þey herde how þat he saide
Where is this fals . treitour this Nereoıı̄un
For feer . ful neer out of his wit he braide
And to His goddis pitously he saide .
For socour but it myȝt nat be tide
For drede of this . him thouȝte þᵗat he deide
And ran in to a gardyn . him to hide
And in this gardyn fond he chorlis tweie
And sitting be . A . fire . gret and reed
And to the chorlis . twe . he gan to preie
To sle him . and . to girde . of his hed .
That to his body whan he were ded
Weere no despit doon . for his defame
Him self he slouȝ . he coude no bettir rede
Of which . fortune lowȝ and had game .
Was . nevir Capteyn . vnder a kyng
That Regnes . mo pot in subiecciou
Ne strenger was in feld of alle thing
As in his tyme ne gretter of renoun
Ne more pompous in hiȝ psumpcion
Than Olophern . whiche fortune atte laste
So licourousli ladde him vp . and doun
Til þat he ded was . or that he wiste
Not onli that this worlde hadde of him awe .
For lesing of riches . and liberte
But he made euery man . reneye his lawe
Nabugodonosor was lord he saide
None othir god sholde honoured be
Ayens his hest þer dar no wiȝt trespas
Saue in Betulia a strong Cite
Where Eliachim was prest of that place
But take kepe of the deth of . Olophern
Amyd . his ost he dronke lay al nyȝt
With ynne his tente large as is A . bern
And ȝit for al his pompe and al his myȝt
Iudith a womman as he lay vpriȝt
Slepinge his hed of smoot and fro his tent
Ful pryueli she stale from euery wiȝt
What nedith it of king Antiochus
To telle hs hiȝ . and rial mageste
His hiȝ pride . his work venemus
For such another man was nevir as he
Redith which that he was in Machabe
And redith the proude workis þat he leide
And whi he fil from His . prosꝑperite
And in an hill how wrecchidli he deide
Fortune . him hadde enhaunsid so in pride
That verrili he wende he myȝte atteyne
Vnto the sterris vp on eueri side
And in a abalaunce to weye . ech mounteyn
And alle þe flodis of þe se restreyn
And goddis pepil hadde . he most in Hate
Hem wolde he sle . in turment and in peyn
Wenynge that god ne myȝte his pride abate
And for Nichamore . and Timothe
With Iuys were . vencusid myȝtily
Vnto the Iuys such an hate had he
That he hadde greithid his . chare ful hastely
And swoor and saide ful despitously
Vnto Ierusalem . he wolde eftsone
To wreke his ire . in it ful cruelly
But of his purpoos was he let ful sone
God for his manace him sore smoot
With inuisibil wounde . ay incurabil
That in his guttis . carf so and boot
That his peynys . were importabil
An certenli þe wreche was vnresonabill
For many a mannys guttis did he peyne
But from his purpoos a cursid ⁊and dampnabil
For al his smert . he nolde him restreyne
But bad anon pareylen his ost
And sodenly or he was waar
God dauntid all his pride and al his bost
For he so sore fil out of his chare
That alle His lymys . and his skyn to tare
So that he ne myȝte go ne ride
But in a chaier men aboute him baar
Al for brosid . bothe . bak . and side
The wreche of god him smot so cruelly
That in his body wickid wormys crepe
And therwith al he stank so horribly
That none of alle his mayne þᵗat him kept
Whethir that he wook or ellis slepte
Ne myȝte not of Hin . the stynk endure
And in this myschief . he wailed and eke wepte
And knew . god lord . of euery creature
To al his ost and to Him self also
Ful waltsom was the stynk . of His careyn
No man myȝte Him bere . to . ne fro
And in his stynk and in his . horrible peyn
He starf ful wrecchidly on a mountayn
Thus hath . this Robber and this homicide
That many a man made to wepe and playn
Such guerdom as belongith vnto pride
The stori of Alisaundir is so comune
That euery wiȝt þat hath discreciou
Hath herd sumwhat or al . of his fortune
This wide worlde as in conclusiou
He wan be strengthe and his Renoun
They were . glad for pees . vnto him sende
The pride of man and beest . he leid a doun
Where so he cam into the worldis ende
Comparison myȝte ȝit nevir be makid
Betwix him and anothir conquerour
For al þis worlde for drede of him hath quakid
He was of knyȝthood . and of fredom flour
Fortune . Him made þe heir of hiȝ honour
Save wyn and wommen no thing myȝt a swage
His hiȝ entent in armys and labour
So was he ful of lovynge corage
What pite were it to him þouȝ I you tolde
Of darius and of a hundrid þousand mo
Of Princis . erlis . kingis bolde
Whhiche he conquerid ⁊and brouȝte Hem to woo
I say as fer as a man may ride or go
The worlde was His . what sholde I more devise
For þouȝ I write . or tolde you euyr mo
Of His knyȝthood it myȝte not suffize
Xij . yeer . he regned Macabe .
Philippis sone of Macedo he was
That first was kyng of grece þat cuntre
O worthi gentil . Alisaunder allas
That euyr sholde falle such acas
Empoysond of thi folk thow were
Thi strong fortune hath tʳnyd into an aas .
And for the ne wepte she nevir ateer
Who shal yeue men teris . to compleyne
To the of gentilnesse . and of Fraunchesie
That all þe worlde weldid in His . demeyn
And ȝit Him þouȝte it myȝte not suffize
So ful was . His . corage . of hiȝ emprise
Allas who shal me helpe to endite
Fals fortune and poison to dispite
The which . of al þis woo I wite
BE wisdom . manhood ⁊and hiȝ labour
From humbilheed ⁊and fro Rial mageste
Vp roos he Iulius the conquerour
That al the occident be londe and se .
Be strengthe of hond or ellis be trete
And vnto Rome made hem tributari
And sith of Rome Emperour was he
Til þat fortune wex . His Aduersari
O myȝti Cesar þat in Thessali
Ayens Pompeius . fadir thin in lawe
That of the orient hadde al þe chiualrie
As fer as þat þe day begynnyth to dawe
They þou þorouȝ knyȝthood . hast take ⁊and slawe
Saue fewe folk þat with Pompeius fledde
Thorou whiche thow . puttist al þᵉ orient in awe
Thanke fortune þat so wel þe spedde
But now a litil while I wil bewail
This Pompeius . this nobil . gouernour
Of Rome whiche þat fley at this bataille
I say on of his men a fals traitour
His hed of smoot to wynne him fauour
Of Iulius and to him the hed brouȝte
Allas Pompeie of the orient conquerour
That fortune vnto such a fyn þe . brouȝte .
To Rome agayn . repeirith Iulius
With His . triumphe laureat ful hie
But on a tyme BrutusCassius
That evir hadde of his hiȝ astat enuye
Ful priuily hadde maad conspiresie
Ayens . this Iulius . in subtil wise
And cast þe place in which he sholde die
With boidekyns . as I . shal you devise
This Iulius vnto þe Capitoly went
Vp on a day as he was wont to gon
And in the Capitoli anon Him hent
This fals Brutus . on his foul foon
And stikid Him with boydekyns anon
With many a wounde ⁊and thus þey leet Him ly
But nevir gruntid He at no strook but oon
Or ellis at wo . but yf his story lye
So manly was this Iulius of herte
And so wel lovid estatly Honeste
That thouȝ . His . dedly woundis so sore smert
His mantel ouer His hippis cast he
For noman sholde se His priuite
And as he lay in dyynge . on . a traunce
And wiste verili that die shulde he
Of honeste . ȝit hadde he Remembraunce
Lucan vnto this story I recomende
And to Suetou and to valery also
That of this story writen . word ⁊and ende
How þat thise conquerouris two
Fortune was first frend ⁊and sithen foo .
Noman truste vp on His fauour longe
But Haue here in awaite for euermo
Witnes on alle the conquerours stronge
The Riche Cresus whilom kyng of lide .
Of whiche Cresus Citrius sore Him drad
Ȝit was he cauȝt amyd al his pride
And to brenne . men to fire him brouȝte
But such arayn doun fro þe firmament shadde
That queynte the fire and made Him to scape
But to be waar ȝit no grace he had
Til fortune on the galowis made Him gape
Whenne . he ascaped was he coude nat stynte
Forto begynne a new ray ayen
He wende wel for that fortune him sent
Such that he a scapid þorou þe Rayn
That of his foos . he myȝte not be slayn
And such a swevyn vp on a nyȝt he mette
Of whiche he was so proude and eke so feyn
That in vengeaunce he all his herte set
Vpon a tre he was as Him thouȝte
There Iubiter Him wessh . bothe Hals ⁊and side
And Phebus eek a . fair towail him brouȝte
To drie him with ⁊and therwith wext his . pride
And to his douȝter that stood him beside .
Which that he knew in hiȝ sentence Habounde
He bad her telle what it signified
And she his dremys . riȝt . thus expouned
The tre quod she . the galowis is to mene
And Iubiter Bekokenyth snow and rayn
And Phebus with his towel so cleen
Tho be the sonne stremys soth to sayn
Thou shalt an hangid be fadir certeyn
Rayn shal the wasshe and sonne shal þe drie
Thus she warned ful . plat and ful pleyn
His douȝter that callid was . Phanye
An hangid was Cresus þe proud kyng
His rial trone myȝte Him not availle
Tragedy is non other maner thing
Ne can in syngrie ne bewaile
For that fortune alday wol assaile
With vnwaar strook þe Regnes that be proude .
For whenne men truste in her than wol she faille
And couer Her briȝt face vnder a cloude
Here endith the monkes tale
HO . quod our ost sir nomore of this
That ye haue said ys ynouȝ ywis
And mykil more . for mykil . heuynes
Is riȝt ynouȝ . to mykil folk y ges .
Your talis doon vs . no disport . ne game
Wherfore sir Monk Piers . Adam . be yoᵘur name
I pray yow hertly tel vs sumwhat ellis
For sikirly nere clynkyng of your bellis
That on your bridil hongyn on eueri side
Be hevyn king that for vs alle dide
I sholde . or this fallen doun for slepe
Alþouȝ þe slowgh hadde nevir be so depe
Thanne hadde your tale al be told in veyn
For certenly as thise clerkis sayn
Where as . aman may haue non . audience
Not helpith . it to telle his sentence
And wel . I woot the substaunce is in me
If ony thing shal wel reportid be
Sere say sumwhat of huntyng I you pray
Nay quod this monk I haue no lust to play
Now lete anothir telle as I haue told
Thanne spak our ost with mylde speche ⁊and bolde
And saide to . the Nonnys prest anone
Com ner thou prest com hidir anon
Tel vs such . thing as may our hertis glade
Be blithe . þouȝ . þou . ride vp on a Iade
What thouȝ . thi hors . be foul and lene
Yf he wol serve the recke the not abene
Loke that thi herte be mery evir mo
Ȝis sir quod he so moot y go
But I be mery I wis I wol be blamyd
And riȝt anon his . tale . he hath attamyd
And thus he saide to vs euerichon
This swete preest this ioly man sir Iohn

l.hi: Here endith þe prolog of þe Nonnys prest

div.l: A pore widow som deel stept in age
Was sumtyme dwellyng in a cotage
Beside a . grove . stondyng in a dale
This widow of whiche I telle my tale
Syn . that day that she was last awyf
In pacience ledde a ful simpil lif
For litil was her catel and her Rent ¶Nonnys Prest
Bi husbondrie such as god her sent
She fond her self and eek her douȝtryn two
Thre large sowis had she . and nomo
Thre kyne . and eek a sheep þᵗat hiȝte Malle
Ful soty was her bour and eek her halle
In whiche she eet meny a slendir meel
Of poynaunt sawce nedith her neuer adeel
Ne deynte morsel passid thorow her throte
Her diet was accordaunt to her cote
Replecion ne made hir neuer sik
A temperat diet was hir phisik
And exxercise and hertis suffisaunce
The gowte lette her no thing forto daunce
Ne replex . shente not her hed
No wyn drank she . whit ne red
Her bord was most servid with whit and blak
Milk and . broun . bred in which she fond no . lak .
Salt bacou and somtyme an ey
For she was as amaner of a dey
A yerd she hadde . enclosid al aboute
With . drie stickis and dichid withoute
In whiche she hadde a cok hiȝte Chauntecleer
In al the lond . of crowyng nas his peer
His vois was merier þan þe mery orgon
On masse daies that in chirche goon
Wel sikir was . his crowyng in his logge
Thanne is a clocke . or ony abbey orlog
Be nature he crew ech assensiou
Of the equinoccian in the . toun
For whenne degrees . xv . were ascendid
Thanne crew . he . that it miȝte not be amendid
His comb was redder . than þe fyn coral
And batellid as it had be a Castel . wal
His bil was blak . as ony geet it shoon
Lik asure were his leggis and his ton ¶Nonnys Prest
His nailis whitter thanne the lili flour
And lik the burned gold was his colour
This gentil cok . hadde in his gouernaunce
Seven hennys . to do his plesaunce
Whiche were his sistris . and his paramouris
And wonder lik to him as of colouris
Of whiche þe fairist hewid in the throte
Was clepid faire damysel Pertelote
Curteis he was discreet and debonaire
And compenabil . and baar hir self so faire
Syn þat tyme þᵗat she was seve nyȝt olde
That trewlich she hath þe herte in hold
Of chauntecleeris lokyng in eueri lith
He loueth her so . þat wel was him þerwith
Whan the briȝt sonne gan to sprynge
In swete accorde my leef is fare in londe
For that tyme as I haue vndirstonde
Bestis and briddis coude speke and synge
And so it fil þat in the dawenynge
Whan þat þe briȝt sonne gan to sprynge
Chauntecleer among . his wivis . alle
Sat on his perche that was in þe halle
And next him sat his faire Pertelote
This Chauntecleer gan to grone in his throte
As aman in his dreme is drecchid sore
And whanne þat Pertelot þus herde him rore
She was agast . and saide herte dere
What eilith . yow . to grone in this manere
Ye be a verry sleper fi for shame
And he ansuerde thus Madame
I pray you þat ye take it not in greef
Be god y mette I was in such myschief
Riȝt now . that myn herte is sore a friȝt
Now . god my sweven he recche ariȝt
And kepe my body out of foul prisou þᵗatd ¶Nonnys Prest
I mette that I romed vp . an doun
With ynne our yerde where y saw abest
Was lik an hounde ⁊and wolde amade reste
Vp on my body and wolde haue had me ded
His colour was . betwixt yelow and reed
And tippid was his tail and bothe . his eris
With blak vnlike þe Remenaunt of his heris
His snowte smal with glowyng yen tweie
Ȝit for his loke almost for feer I deye
This causith me my gronyng doutles
Awey quod she fy . for shame hertlees
Allas quod she . for be god aboue
Now haue ye lost myn herte and al my loue
I can not loue a cowarde be my feith
For certis what so ony womman seith
We alle desiren . yf it myȝte be .
To haue husbondis hardy wise and fre .
And secret and non nygard ne no fool
Ne him that is . agast of euery tool
Ne none avauntour be god above
How durst ye sey for shame vnto yoᵘur love
That ony þing myȝte make you a feerde
Haue ye no mannys herte . and haue a berde
Allas and conne ye be aferd of swevenys
No thing but vanite god woot in swevene is
Sweuenys engendry of replecioun
And of synne . and of complexiou
Whenne humouris been to habundaunt in a wiȝt
Certis this . dreme which ye haue met to nyȝt
Comyth of your suꝑparfluite
⁊and reed colour parde
Which causeth folk to dreden in her dremys
Of arowis . and of fire with rede lemys
Of grete bestis þat wol ham bite
Riȝt as the humour of malencolite
Causith many aman in slepe to crie
And al this . comyth of mannys folie
And for feer . of grete bolis and beris blake
Or ellis blake devellis . wol hem take
Of humouris . coude I telle also
That worken many aman in slepe mykil wo
But I wil passe as liȝtly as I can
Lo caton which þat was a wise man
Saide he not thus . do no fors of dremys
Now sir quod she . whanne we fle fro the bemys
For goddis loue as takith sum laxatif
Vp peril of my soule and my lif
I counsel you þe best I wol nat lye
That bothe of coler and of malencolie
Ye purge you and for ye shul not tary
Thogh in this toun be non apotecary
I shal my self . to herbis teche yow
That shal be for your hele ⁊and for your prow
And in your herbis yerd tho herbis shal I fynde
The whiche haue of her proꝑper kynde
To purge you benethe and eke above
Foryet not this for goddis owen love
Ye be riȝt colerik . of complexiou
Waar the sonne in his ascensiou
Ne fynde ye not of humours . hote
For yf it do I dar ley agrote
Thanne shal . ye haue a fevir tercian
Or an agew that may be your bane
A . day . or . two . ye shul haue digestyvis
Of wormys . or ye take your laxativis
Of laureal . centory and of fumetere
Or ellis of the olderberyes . þᵗat growyn theer
Of Catapuce . or of gaitberiez
Of herbe yve growyng in yoᵘur yerd þᵗat mery ys ¶Nonnys Prest
Pluk hem vp as they growe and ete hem yn
Be mery husbond for your fadir kyn
Dredith no dreme I kan say you nomore
Madame quod he gramercy of your lore
But natheles as touching Catoun
That of wisdom such a gret renoun
That he bad no dremys forto drede
Be god men may in olde bokis rede
Of many aman more of auctorite
Than euyr Caton was so moot y the
That al the reuers say of his sentence
And haue wel founde be experience
That dremys be significaciouns
As wel of ioie as of tribulacions
That folk enduryn in this lif psent
Ther nedith to make of this non argument
The verry preef shewith it in dede
One of the grettest auctor that men rede
Saith thus that sumtyme two felowis went
On pilgremage in ful good entent
And happid so they comyn in atoun
Where as þer was such . congregaciou
Of pepil . and eke of streit herbegage
That þey ne fond as mykil as a cotage
In whiche þey bothe myȝte I loggid be
Wherfore they muste of necessite
As for that nyȝt . departe companye
And ech of them goth . to his osterie
And took his logging as it wold falle
That on of ham was loggid in a stalle
Ferd in þe yerde with oxen of þe plow
That othir man was loggid wel ynow
As was his auenture . or his fortune
That vs . gouernyth al as infortune ¶Nonnys Prest
And so it be fil . longe . or it were day
This man mette in his bed þere þat he lay
That his felow . gan to him calle
And saide allas . for in an oxes stalle
This nyȝt shal I be murdrid þere I ly
Now help me dere brother . or I dy
In alle haste com to me he saide
This man out of his slepe for feer abreide
An whanne he was wakid of his slepe
He turned him and took of this no kepe
Him þouȝte his . dreme bu was but a vanite
Thus twise in his slepe dremyd he .
And atte thridde tyme ȝit his felaw
Cam as him þouȝte and saide I am now slawe
Behold my blody woundis depe and wide
Arise vp erly in þe morow tide
And atte west . gate of the toun quod he
A cartful of dung þere shalt þou se
In whiche my body is hid ful pryuely
Do that carte areste boldely
Mi gold causid my deth soth to sayn
And tolde him euery poynt how he was slayn
With a ful pitous face . pale of hewe
And trust wel his dreme he fond . riȝt . trewe
For on þe morow as sone as it was day
To his felowis yn he took þe way
And whenne þat he cam . to his oxis stalle
Aftir his felow . he gan to calle
The Osteler answerd him anon
And saide ser your felow is goon
As sone as day he wente out of the toun
This man . gan fallyn in suspessioun
Remembryng of his dremys that he mette
And forth he goth no lengir wolde he lette ¶Nonnys Prest
Vnto the Westgate of þe toun and fond
A dong Carte . as it were to donge londe
That was araid in the same wise
As ye haue herd þe ded man devise
And with hardy herte he gan . to crie
Venyaunce and Iustice of . this felonye
Mi felow . murdrid is . this . same . nyȝt
And in this carte he lith gaping vpriȝt
I crie out on the Ministres quod he
That sholde kepe . and reule this Cite
Harow . allas here lith . my felow slayn
What sholde y more of this tale sayn
The pepil out sterte and cast þe carte to grounde
And in þe myddel of the dong þey fonde
The ded man that mordrid was al newe
O blesful god that art so good . and trewe
Lo . how . that thow bewreyest murdir alwey
Mordir wol out that se we day be day
Mordir is so waltsom and abhomynabil
To god that Iust is and resonable
That he ne wol it suffre helid . to be
They . it abide aday . or two . or thre
Mordir wol out this is my conclusiou
And riȝt anon Ministris of the toun
Haue hent the carter ⁊and so sore him peyned
And eke the Osteler so sore engyned
That they beknew hir wickidnesse anon
And weren an hangid be the necke boon
Here may ye se . that dremys bith . to drede
And certis in the same lif I rede
Riȝt in the nexte chapitre aftir this
I gab not so haue I ioie and blis
Two men þᵗat wolde haue passid ouer þe se
For certayn causis into a fer contre . ¶Nonnys Prest
Yf the wynd . ne hadde be contrarie
That made hem in a cite to tarye
That stood ful mery vp on an haven side
But on aday . ayens an evyn tide
The wynd . gan . chaunge ⁊and blew as him list
Ioli and glad they wentyn . to rest .
And cast hem ful erly forto saile
But herkyn to þᵗat on man fil a greet mvaile
The on of ham . slepinge as he lay
He mette a wonder dreme agayn the day
Him þouȝte aman . stood bi his beddis side
And him comaundid that he sholde abide
And saide him . thus yf thow . to morow wende
Thow shalt be dreynt my tale is at an ende
He wook . and tolde his felow . what he mette
And praide him his viage forto lette
As for that day he praide him forto abide
His . felow . that lay be his beddis side
Gan forto lauȝe . and scornyd him ful faste
No dreme quod he . may do my herte agaste
That I wol lette forto do my . thingis
I set nat a strawe . for thi dremyngꝭes
For swevenys be . but vanitees . and Iapes
Men metyn alday of owlis and of apis
And of many amase therwith al
And dremyn . of thing þat nevir was ne shal
But sith I se . that þou wolt here abide
And thus slouthen wilfully . thi . tide
God woot it rewith me . and haue good day
And thus he . took his leve and wente his way
But er he hadde half his cours ysailed
I not whi ne what myschaunce it aylid
But casuelly . þe shippis botom to rent

In siȝte of othir shippis beside

And þerfore faire Pertelot so dere
Bi ensamplis olde maist thou here
That noman sholde be to recheles
Of dremys for I say the doutles
That many a dreme ful sore is forto drede
Lo . in the lif of saint Kenelme y rede
That was Kenulphus sone þe nobil kyng
Of mereturik how Kenelme mette a . thing
A litil or he were mordrid . on aday
His mordir in his vision . he say
His norissh . him expouned it everidell
His swevyn . and bad him kepe him wel
Fro treson . but he . was but .vij. yeer old
And þerfore litil tale he hath þerof told
Of ony dreme so holi was his herte
Be god I hadde levir than my sherte
That ye hadde herd his legend as haue I
Dame Pertelot I say . to yow . trewly
Macrobius that writith the visioun
Affermyth dremys . and saith . that þey . been
Warnyng of thingis þat we aftir seen
And ferthermore I pray yow . lokith wel
In þe olde testament of daniell

Warnyng of thingis þᵗat shul aftir fal

His baker and his boteler also

But he was slayn anone of Achilles
But þat tale is to long to telle
And eek it is nyȝ . nyȝt I may not dwelle
Shortly I say as for conclusiou

For also sikir as in principio

Madame þe sentence of this latyn is
Womman is mannys Ioie and his blis
For whenne I fele an nyȝt your softe side

And to him þanne ran his wivis alle

Leue I this Chauntcleer in his pasture
And aftir wol I telle . of his auenture
Whan þe moneth in þe whiche þᵉ worlde began

Was compleet . and passid were also
Sith Marche began . was . thritty daies ⁊and two
Befil . þat Chauntecleer in al his pride

That in the signe of taurus was y ronne
Twenti degrees . and oon . ⁊and on sumwhat more
He knew be kynde and be non other lore
That it was pryme ⁊and crew wᵗith a blisful stevyn
