Fourty degrees and one ⁊and sumwhat more Iwys
Madame Pertelote . my worldis blis
Harkyn how this blisful briddis synge
And se the fressh . flouris how they sprynge
Ful is myn herte of Revel and solas
But sodenly him fil a sorouful caas .
For euer þe latter ende of ioie is sone ago ¶Nonnys Prest
And comynly often tyme it fallith so
And yf a rother coude faire endite
He in a croniculer myȝte savely write
As for souereyn notabilite
Now euery wiseman herkyn to me
This story is al so trewe I vndertake
As is the book of launcelot delake
That wommen holden in ful gret Reủerence
Now wol I turne ayen . to my sentence
A col fox ful of sleiȝte . and iniquite
That in the grove hadde woned yeris thre
Be hiȝ ymaginacion . aforn cast
The same nyȝt . thorouȝ þe heggis brast
Into the yerd . there Chauntecleer þe faire
Was . wont and eke his wyvis to repaire
And in a bed of wortis stille he lay
Til . it was passid vndren of the day
Waitynge . his tyme . on chauntecleer to falle
As . gladli doon thise homicides alle
That in . a . waite ligge . to murdre men
A fals murderour vnckyng in thi den
O newe scariot . and newe Genylioun
Fals dissimilour . o . greek . Synou
That brouȝttist troie vttirly to sorow
O chauntecleer . acursid be the morow .
That thou in thi yerd fley fro the bemys
Thow were ful wel warnyd be . thi dremys
That ilke day was parlous to the .
But that god afore woot muste nedis . be .
Aftir the oppinion . of certeyn . clerkis
Witnes of him that ony clerk is
That in . scole is . gret . altercaciou
In this mater . and . gret . disputaciou
And hath ben . of an hundrid thousand men . ¶Nonnys Prest
But I ne can not bulte out the brenne
As can . the holi doctour . Austyn
Or boece . or the bisshop . Bradwardyn
Whethir þat goddis wil afore wetynge
Streynyth me needles . to do a . thing
Nedly clepe I sympil necessite
Or yf the fre choys be grauntid me
To do þat same thing or do it nouȝt
Thowȝ god forwoot it or it was wrouȝt
Or yf his witynge streyneth nevir adeel
But by necessite condicionell
I wol not haue to doon of such matere
Mi tale is of . a cook as ye shul here
That took his counsel of his wif wᵗith sorow .
To walke in the yerde vp on the morow .
That he hadde met the dreme as I you tolde
Wommennys counsellis . be ful ofte colde
Wommannys counsel . brouȝte vs first to woo
And made Adam . fro paradis to go
There as he was ful mery and wel at ese .
But for I not whom y myȝte displese
If I counsel of wommen wolde blame
Passe ouer y saide it in my game
Redith auctours where þey trete of such matere
And what they say of wommen ye mowe here
These been the cokkis wordis and not myn
I can no harm . of no womman devyne
Faire in the sond to bathe hir merily
Lith Pertelot and alle her susteris by
Ayens þe sonne and Chauntecleer so free
Sang merier þan the marmaide in þe se
For phisalogus saith vttirly
How þat þey syngen wel and merily
And so be fil . as he cast his ye ¶Nonnys Prest
Among the wortis on a . botirflie
He was . waar of this fox . þat lay ful lowe
No thing thanne lust him forto crowe
But cride anon . cok . cok . and vp he stert
As man þat was afraid in his hert
For naturelly . a best desirith to fle
Fro his contrary yf he may it se
They he nevir had seyn it erst with his ye
This Chauntecleer . whan he gan him aspie
He wolde haue fled but þat þe fox anon
Saide . gentil sere allas what wil ye don
Be ye affraid of me that am your frende
Certis sere thanne be ye vnkynd
If I to you wolde harm . or vilonye
I am not comyn your counsel to aspie
But trewly þe cause of my comynge
Was only to here how ye syng
For trewly . ye haue as mery a stevyn
As ony aungel hath þat is in hevyn
Therwith . ye haue of musik more felynge
Than hadde boys . or ony þat can syng
Mi lord your fadir god his soule blis
And eke your moder of her gentilnes
Haue in my hous be ful wel at ese
And certis ser fayne wolde I you plese
But for men speke of syngyng I wolde sey
So moot y browkyn . myn yen . twey
Saue you ne herd I neuer man so synge
As did your fader in þe mornynge
Certis it was of herte al that he sang
And forto make his vois þe more strang
He wolde so peyne him þᵗat wᵗith . bothe his yen
He muste wynke . so lowde he muste crien
And stondyn on his tiptoos . þerwith all ¶Nonnys Prest
And strecche forth his necke long and smal
And eek he was . of such discreciou
That ther was noman in no Regioıı̄un
That him in song or wisdom . myȝte passe
I haue wel red . dan burnel the asse
Among his vers . ther was a cok
For a prestis sone yaf him a . knok
Vp on his leggis while he was yong and nyce
He made him forto lese his bnfice
But þer is no comparisou
Betwix wisdom and discreciou
Of your fadir . and of his subtilite
Now syngith sere for saint charite
Lete se . can ye your fadir countirfete
This chauntecleer his wyngis gan bete
As man that coude nat his reson aspie
So was he rauysshed with his flaterie
Allas ye Lordis many a fals flaterour
Is in your court and meny a fals losingour
That plese you more be my feith
Thanne he þᵗat softfasnes . vnto you saith
Redith . ecclesiast of flaterie
Be waar ye lordis of her trecherie
This Chauntecleer stood hie vp on his toos
Strecching his necke and held his yen . cloos .
And gan . to crowe loude for the nonys
And Dan Russel start vp . at onys
And bi the gorge . hente chauntecleer
And on his bak . toward þe wode him beer
For ȝit was þer noman that him suyd
O . destene . that maist not be eschuyd
Allas þᵗat Chauntecleer fley fro the bemys
Allas his wif rauȝt not of dremys
And on a friday fil . al this myschaunce ¶Nonnys Prest
O venus . that art god of plesaunce
Sithnes . þat thi seruᵃnt was . this chauntecleer
And in thi seruize . dide al . his power
More forto delite thanne the worlde . to multiplie
Whi woldist thou . suffre . hym on thi day . to die
O gaufride . dere maistir souereyn
That whanne thi worthi kyng Richard was sleyn
With shot compleinedist his . deth so sore
Whi ne hadde y now . thi sentence ⁊and thi lore
The friday forto chidyn as did . ye
For on a friday . shortly slayn was he
Thanne wolde y shewe you how þᵗat I coude pleyn
For chauntecleer and for his peyn
Certis such cry ne lamentaciou
Was of ladies maad whenne Ilion was wonne
And Pirrus with his streyȝt swerd
When he hent kyng Priam be the berd
And slow him as saith Ennydose
As maden alle the hennys in þe cloos
Whenne þat þey hadde of chauntecler þᵉ siȝt
But souerenly dame Pertelot . gan to shriȝt
Ful lowder than did . Asdrubalis wif
Whenne þat her husbond had lost his lif
And that þe Romayns had brent Cartage
She was so ful of turment and of rage
That wilfully in to the fire she stert
And brende her self with a stedfast hert
O woful hennys so that criden ye
As whenne þat Nero brent þe cite
Of Rome criden the Senatouris wivis
For þat her husbondis sholde leȝe her lyvis
Withoutyn gilt . Nero hath ham sleyn
Now wol . I turne to my tale . agayn
This seli widow ⁊and hir douȝtris two . ¶Nonnys Prest
Herden þe hennys crie and make woo
And out at the dore stert þey anone
And saw the fox . toward þe wode goon
And baar vp on his bak þe cok awey
And criden . out ⁊and harow and welawey
A . ha . the fox . and aftir him þey renne
And eek with stavis meny . othir menne
Ran . colle our dogge . talbat and garlonde
And Malkyn with her distaf in her honde
Ran . cow . and eek þe very hoggis
For þey so sore a ferd were of the doggis
And showtyng of men . and of wommen eek
They ronne so her herte þouȝte to breke
They yellyn as fendis doon in helle
The doggis criden as men wolde hem quelle
Out of the hivis com the swarm of bees
The goos for feer fley ouer þe trees
So hidous was þe noise . a . benedicite
Certis Iacke Straw ne his meyne
Ne made nevir shoutis half so shille
Whenne þᵗat þey wolde eny flemyng kille
As that day was maad vp on þe fox
Of bras þey brekyn the bemys ⁊and of box
Of horn and boon in whiche þey poupid
And therwith þey shritid and showtid
It semed as thouȝ hevyn sholde falle
Now godemen I pray you . harkyn alle
Lo how . fortune turnyth sodenly
The hope and the pride of her envy
This cok hath leye vp on this foxis bak
In al his drede vnto þe fox he spak
And saide sere yf I were as . ye
Ȝit sholde I say as wis god help me
Turnyth . ayeen ye proude chorlis alle ¶Nonnys Prest
A verri pestilence vp on you falle
Now . am y come vnto this wodis side
Magre your hed the cok shal here abide
I wol . him ete in feith and that anon
The fox . ansuerde in feith it shal be doon
And as he spak þe word al sodenly
This cok brak from his mouth delyuerly
And hiȝ vp on atree he fly anon
An whenne þe fox saw þᵗat he was goon
Alas quod he . o . chauntecler alas
I haue do . to yow . greet trespas
In as muche as I made you aferde
Whenne I yow hente ⁊and brouȝte out of yoᵘur yerde
But sere y did yt not in no wickid entent
Com doun . and I shal telle you what I ment
I shal you say soth . so god helpe me so .
Nay thanne quod he I shrewe vs bothe two
And first I shrewe my self bothe blood ⁊and bonys
If þou begile me oftir þanne onys
Thow shalt nomore with thi flaterie
Do me synge with a wynkyng . ye
For he þat wynketh whanne he sholde se
As wisly . god lete him nevir the
Nay quod þe fox god yeve me myschaunce
That is so vndiscreet of gouernaunce
That iangelith when þat he sholde haue pees
Lo such it is forto be recheles
And negligent and truste on flaterie
But ye þat holdyn þis tale a folie
As of a fox . and a cok . ⁊and an hen
Takith þe moralite gode men
For saint Poule saith al þᵗat writyn is
To r our doctryne is writyn Iwis
Thakith þe fruyt ⁊and leet þe chaf be stille
Now gode men yf þat it be your wille
As seith my lorde so make vs alle gode men
And brynge vs to his hiȝ blisse Amen

div.ab: (base) ¶ Preces de Chauceres .

(base) Now preye I to hem alle that herkne this litel tretys or rede
that if ther be any thyng in it that liketh hem that ther of
they thanken oure lorde Ihesu crist of whom procedeth al
wit and al goodnesse

(base) And if ther be any thyng that displese hem I
preye hem also that they arrette it to the defaute of myn vnkonnynge
and nat to my wyl that wolde ful fayn haue seyd bettre if I hadde
had konnynge

(base) For oure book seith Al that is writen is writen for
oure doctrine and that is myn entente

(base) Wherfore I biseke yow
mekely for the mercy of god that ye preye for me that crist haue mercy
on me and foryeue me my giltes

(base) and namely of my translacions
and enditynges of worldly vanitees the whiche I reuoke in my retracciouns

(base) As is the book of Troilus The book also of Fame The
book of the xxvladies The book of the duchesse The book of
seint Valentynes day of the perlement of briddes The tales of
Caunterbury thilke that sownen in to synne

(base) The book of the Leoun
and many another book if they were in my remembrance and
many a song and many a leccherous lay that crist for his grete mercy foryeue me the synne

(base) But of the translacioun of Boece
de consolaciou and othere bookes of legendes of Seintes and
Omelies and moralitee and deuocioun

(base) that thanke I oure
lord Ihesu crist and his blisful mooder and alle the seintes of heuene

(base) bisekynge hem that they from hennes forth vn to my lyues
ende sende me grace to biwayle my giltes and to studie to the
saluacioun of my soule and graunte me grace of verray penitence confessioun and satisfaccioun to doon in this persent lyf

(base) thurgh
the benigne grace of hym that is kyng of kynges and preest
ouer alle preestes that boghte vs with the precious blood of his herte

(base) so that I may been oon of hem at the day of doome that shulle
be saued Qui cum patre et cetera
